1.title: The birth of the Prophet Muhammad, son of Abdullah, peace be upon him.
1.details: The biographers and historians have differed in determining the day, month, and year of his birth, peace be upon him, but they agreed that his birth, peace be upon him, was on a Monday in the Year of the Elephant. Ibn al-Qayyim said: "There is no dispute that he was born, peace be upon him, in the heart of Mecca, and that his birth was in the Year of the Elephant." It is narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: (The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was born in the Year of the Elephant), and this is what no scholar doubts. Khalifa ibn Khayyat, Ibn al-Jazari, Ibn Dihya, and Ibn al-Jawzi have reported consensus on this. As for his birth on Monday, it is narrated from Abu Qatadah al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: "The Prophet, peace be upon him, was asked about fasting on Mondays. He said: 'That is the day I was born, and the day I was sent (as a prophet) or the revelation was sent down to me.'" Ibn Kathir said: "Far be it, nay, he erred, who said: He was born on Friday the seventeenth of Rabi' al-Awwal." The point of disagreement was in determining the month and the day within it. Ibn Ishaq narrated from a group of the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, that they said to him: "O Messenger of Allah, tell us about yourself." He said: (Yes, I am the supplication of my father Abraham, and the good news of Jesus, and my mother saw when she was pregnant with me that a light emerged from her that illuminated the palaces of Syria for her). His birth, peace be upon him, was after the death of his father Abdullah, as he was a fetus in his mother's womb when his father passed away, so the Prophet, peace be upon him, grew up an orphan. His birth took place in the house of Abu Talib in the valley of Banu Hashim.
1.location_name: The house of Abu Talib in the Shi'b of Banu Hashim

2.title: The first incident of the Prophet's chest being opened.
2.details: Anas bin Malik narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was playing with some boys when Gabriel, peace be upon him, came to him. Gabriel took him and laid him down, then opened his chest and took out his heart. He extracted a clot from it and said, "This is the devil's share of you." Then he washed it in a golden basin with Zamzam water, then sewed it up, and returned it to its place. The boys came running to his mother – meaning his wet nurse – and said, "Muhammad has been killed!" They met him, and his complexion had changed. Anas said, "I used to see the mark of that stitch on his chest."

3.title: The death of the Prophet's mother, Aminah bint Wahb, and the upbringing of the Prophet, peace be upon him, by Umm Ayman.
3.details: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, reached six years of age, his mother, the noble Aminah bint Wahb, took him to visit her maternal uncles, Banu Adi ibn al-Najjar, accompanied by his wet nurse, Umm Ayman, may Allah be pleased with her. They were traveling on two camels. His mother disembarked with him at the house of al-Nabighah, near the grave of his father, Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib. She stayed with her relatives for a month, and then his mother returned with him to Mecca. When they reached Al-Abwa, his mother Aminah bint Wahb passed away. Umm Ayman, may Allah be pleased with her – whose name was Barakah bint Tha'labah ibn Hisn – returned with him. Umm Ayman, may Allah be pleased with her, loved the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, with an intense love and cared for him with the utmost attention, protecting him with her care and compassion. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was dutiful to her and treated her kindly. When he grew older, peace and blessings be upon him, he freed her, and then married her to Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, by whom she had Usamah ibn Zayd, may Allah be pleased with them both. Umm Ayman, may Allah be pleased with her, passed away five months after the passing of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

4.title: The guardianship of Abdul Muttalib over the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and his knowledge of his affairs.
4.details: When Aminah, the mother of the Messenger, peace be upon him, passed away while he was six years old, his guardianship fell to his grandfather, Abdul Muttalib ibn Hashim. Abdul Muttalib was a man of honor and virtue among his people, and Quraysh called him "Al-Fadl" (the Virtuous) due to his generosity and merit. He assumed the responsibilities of Rifadah (providing food for pilgrims) and Siqayah (providing water for pilgrims) after the death of his father, Hashim ibn Abd Manaf. Abdul Muttalib loved his grandson Muhammad with a great love, preferring him over all his other sons and showing him more tenderness than he showed his own children. Ibn Ishaq, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was with his grandfather Abdul Muttalib ibn Hashim – meaning, after the death of his mother Aminah bint Wahb. A bed would be laid for Abdul Muttalib in the shade of the Kaaba, and his sons would sit around that bed until he came out to it. None of his sons would sit on it out of reverence for him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would come as a young boy, strong and full, and sit on it. His uncles would try to pull him away from it, but when Abdul Muttalib saw that, he would say, 'Leave my son; by Allah, he has a great destiny.' Then he would seat him with him on his bed, stroke his back with his hand, and be pleased with what he saw him do." Abdul Muttalib would not eat food unless he said, "Bring my son to me!" and he would be brought to him. When Abdul Muttalib was nearing death, he bequeathed to Abu Talib the care and protection of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

5.title: The death of Abdul Muttalib and his bequest of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to Abu Talib.
5.details: When the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, reached eight years of age, his grandfather, Abd al-Muttalib, passed away. When Abd al-Muttalib was on his deathbed, he entrusted his son, Abu Talib, with the care and protection of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and to look after him. He entrusted him to Abu Talib because Abdullah, the father of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Talib were from the same mother. So, when Abd al-Muttalib died, Abu Talib was the one who took charge of the affairs of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, after his grandfather. Ibn Sa'd and Ibn Asakir narrated from Ibn Abbas, may God be pleased with them, and others, who said: When Abd al-Muttalib passed away, Abu Talib took the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and he would stay with him. Abu Talib loved him with an intense love, not loving his own children as much. He would not sleep except next to him, and he would favor him with food. When Abu Talib's children ate together or individually, they would not be full. But if the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, ate with them, they would be full. When Abu Talib intended to give them breakfast or dinner, he would say, "Wait until my son arrives." Then the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, would come and eat with them, and they would have leftovers from their food. If he was not with them, their food would not be enough to fill them. If it was milk, he would drink first, then the children would take a large bowl, like a platter, and drink from it until they were all satisfied from that single bowl. One of them would even drink a whole bowl by himself. Abu Talib would then say, "Indeed, you are blessed!"

6.title: The Prophet's journey with his uncle Abu Talib to Syria.
6.details:
When the Prophet, peace be upon him, reached the age of twelve years, his uncle Abu Talib traveled to the Levant on a trade caravan, and he took him along. When the caravan camped at Busra, they passed by a monk there named Bahira, who was knowledgeable in the Gospel and an expert in Christianity. It was there that Bahira saw the Prophet, peace be upon him, and he began to observe him and speak with him. Then he turned to Abu Talib and asked, "Who is this boy to you?" Abu Talib replied, "He is my son." (Abu Talib used to call him his son due to his intense love and compassion for him). Bahira said, "He is not your son, and it is not fitting that the father of this boy should be alive." Abu Talib said, "He is my nephew." Bahira asked, "What happened to his father?" Abu Talib replied, "He died while his mother was pregnant with him." Bahira said, "You have spoken the truth. Return him to his land and beware of the Jews, for by God, if they see him here, they will wish him great harm. For this nephew of yours is destined for a great matter." Abu Talib hastened back to Mecca with him.

Al-Tirmidhi narrated that Abu Talib went out to the Levant, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, went out with him along with some elders of Quraysh. When they approached the monk (meaning Bahira), they dismounted and set up their camp. The monk came out to them. Previously, they used to pass by him, but he would not come out to them or pay them any attention. As they were setting up their camp, the monk went among them until he came and took the hand of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and said, "This is the master of the worlds, this is the Messenger of the Lord of the worlds, whom Allah will send as a mercy to the worlds." Some elders of Quraysh said to him, "What is your knowledge of this?" He replied, "When you approached from the mountain pass, no tree or stone remained but bowed in prostration, and only prophets bow in prostration. And I know him by the Seal of Prophethood below the cartilage of his shoulder, like an apple." Then he went back and prepared food for them. When he brought it to them, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, was tending to the camels, he said, "Send for him." The Prophet, peace be upon him, came, and a cloud shaded him. When he approached the people, he found that they had preceded him to the shade of the tree. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sat down, the shade of the tree moved to cover him. Bahira said, "Look at the shade of the tree, how it has moved to him!" While he was standing among them, he implored them not to take him to the Romans, for if the Romans saw him, they would recognize him by his description and kill him. He looked and saw seven men approaching from the direction of Rome. He met them and asked, "What brings you here?" They said, "We have come because this Prophet is to emerge this month. No road was left without people being sent to it, and we have been informed of his news, so we were sent to this road of yours." He asked, "Did anyone who is better than you precede you?" They said, "We were only informed of his news for this road of yours." He asked, "If Allah wills something to happen, can any person prevent it?" They said, "No." He said, "Then pledge allegiance to him, and they stayed with him." The monk Bahira said, "I adjure you by Allah, who is his guardian?" Abu Talib said, "He kept imploring him until Abu Talib returned him."

7.title: The War of al-Fijār, and the Prophet's witnessing of it, peace be upon him.
7.details: When the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, reached fourteen or fifteen years of age, the War of Al-Fijar broke out between Quraysh and those with them from Kinanah, and Qays Aylan. This was one of the greatest days of the Arabs. The cause of this war was that Urwah Al-Rahhal, son of Utbah bin Rabiah, granted protection to a caravan belonging to Al-Nu'man bin Al-Mundhir. Al-Barrad bin Qays, one of the Banu Damrah bin Bakr bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah, said to him, "Will you protect it against Kinanah?" He replied, "Yes, and against all creation." So Urwah Al-Rahhal set out, and Al-Barrad followed him, seeking an opportunity. When they were at Tayman Dhi Dhilal in Al-Aliyah, Urwah was caught unaware. Al-Barrad attacked him and killed him during the sacred month. This is why it was called the War of Al-Fijar. A messenger came to Quraysh and said, "Al-Barrad has killed Urwah during the sacred month at Ukaz." They set out, and Hawazin were unaware. Then the news reached them, and they pursued them, catching up to them before they entered the sanctuary. They fought until nightfall, and then they entered the sanctuary, so Hawazin ceased their pursuit. After this day, the people met for many days, with each tribe of Quraysh and Kinanah having a leader from among them, and each tribe of Qays having a leader from among them. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, witnessed some of their days, including the Day of Al-Nakhlah, when he was fourteen years old. Some say twenty years old. After their return from it, in Dhu al-Qi'dah, the Pact of Al-Fudul took place. The reason for it was that a man from Zabid, from Yemen, sold goods to Al-As bin Wa'il Al-Sahmi, who delayed paying him the price. The man climbed Mount Abu Qubais and cried out, mentioning his grievance. Quraysh then formed the Pact of Al-Fudul to support the oppressed. The Prophet, peace be upon him, witnessed this pact with them.

8.title: The Pact of the Virtuous among the tribes of Quraysh.
8.details: The Hilf al-Fudul (Alliance of the Virtuous) took place in a sacred month. Tribes of Quraysh were called to it: Banu Hashim, Banu Muttalib, Asad ibn Abd al-Uzza, Zuhrah ibn Kilab, and Taym ibn Murrah. They gathered in the house of Abdullah ibn Jud'an al-Taymi, due to his age and nobility. They made a pact and a covenant that if they found anyone oppressed in Mecca, whether from its people or others, they would stand with him and be against whoever oppressed him until his rights were restored. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, witnessed this alliance and said about it: "I witnessed an alliance in the house of Abdullah ibn Jud'an that I would not exchange for a herd of red camels, and if I were called to it in Islam, I would respond." This alliance contradicted the spirit of tribalistic pride that partisanship stirred. It is said that the reason for this alliance was that a man from Zubayd came to Mecca with merchandise, which Al-As ibn Wail al-Sahmi bought from him but withheld his payment. The man sought help from the allied tribes of Abd al-Dar, Makhzum, Jumah, Sahm, and Adi, but they paid him no heed. He then climbed Mount Abu Qubays and called out with verses describing his oppression, raising his voice. Al-Zubayr ibn Abd al-Muttalib then went forth and said, "This cannot be left as is." They gathered and formed the alliance known as Hilf al-Fudul. Then they went to Al-As ibn Wail and retrieved the Zubaydi's right. The reason for its naming is that three men from the Jurhum tribe, namely Al-Fadl ibn Fadalah, Al-Fadl ibn Wada'ah, and Al-Fadl ibn al-Harith, had previously made a similar agreement. When the actions of the Quraysh resembled the actions of these early Jurhumis, all of whom were named Al-Fadl, the alliance was named Hilf al-Fudul.

9.title: The marriage of the Prophet, peace be upon him, to Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her.
9.details:
There are differing opinions regarding the age of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the age of Khadijah when they married. It has been said that he was twenty-five. It has also been said that he was twenty-seven. And it has been said that he was thirty. And other opinions have been stated. As for the age of Khadijah, the sayings also vary between thirty-five, forty, and other ages.

When Khadijah, may Allah be pleased with her, heard about the Prophet, peace be upon him, his trustworthiness, and his noble character, it is narrated that Khadijah's sister hired the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and his partner for a journey. When they completed the journey, some payment was still due to her. Her partner began to approach them to collect the dues, and he would say to Muhammad, peace be upon him: "Go." Muhammad would reply: "You go, for I feel shy." One time, when her partner came to them, she asked: "Where is Muhammad? Why doesn't he come with you?" He said: "I told him, but he claimed he felt shy." She mentioned this to her sister Khadijah, who said: "I have never seen a man more shy, more chaste, or... than Muhammad, peace be upon him." This impressed Khadijah, so she sent for him and said: "Go to my father and propose to him." He said: "Your father is a man of great wealth, and he will not agree to this." She said: "Go, meet him and speak to him, and I will handle the rest." The Prophet, peace be upon him, married her while she was a widow.

10.title: The Prophet's journey to Syria for the second time.
10.details:
When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, reached twenty-five years of age, he had no name in Mecca except "Al-Amin" (The Trustworthy), due to the perfection of his good qualities. His uncle, Abu Talib, said to him: "O nephew, I am a man with no wealth, and times have become harsh upon us, and we have been afflicted by severe years. We have no provisions or trade. Your people's caravan is ready to depart for Syria, and Khadijah bint Khuwaylid is sending men from your people with her caravans to trade her wealth, and they gain profits. If you were to approach her and offer yourself for her business, she would hasten to you and prefer you over others, due to what she has heard of your purity. Although I dislike you going to Syria and fear for you from the Jews, we have no choice."

Khadijah bint Khuwaylid was a merchant woman of noble lineage, great wealth, and extensive trade that she sent to Syria. Her caravans were like those of the rest of Quraysh. She used to hire men and give them money for trade on a profit-sharing basis. News of the Prophet's truthful speech, his great trustworthiness, and his noble character reached Khadijah. So, she sent for him to manage her trade. He set out with her servant Maysarah until they reached Syria. His uncles had instructed the caravan members to look after him until he reached Syria. They camped in the market of Busra, under a tree near the monastery of a monk named Nestorius. The monk looked at Maysarah, whom he recognized, and said: "O Maysarah, who is this who has camped under this tree?" Maysarah replied: "A man from Quraysh, from the people of the Sanctuary." The monk said: "No one has ever camped under this tree except a prophet." Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sold his goods, meaning his merchandise, and bought what he intended to buy. He then set off, returning to Mecca with Maysarah. When he arrived in Mecca with Khadijah's wealth, she sold what had come back for double its value or close to it. Maysarah told her about the monk's words and what he had witnessed of the Prophet's affairs. Thereupon, she proposed herself to him, may Allah be pleased with her. She was of the noblest lineage among the women of Quraysh, the most honorable, and the wealthiest. When she said this to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he mentioned it to his uncles. His uncle Hamzah went with him and approached Khuwaylid ibn Asad to propose marriage. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, married her. She was the first woman he married, and he did not marry anyone else until she passed away, may Allah be pleased with her.

11.title: The Prophet, peace be upon him, places the Black Stone in its place in the Kaaba.
11.details: From Mujahid, from his freedman, that he told him: I was among those building the Kaaba in the pre-Islamic era... He said: We built until we reached the place of the Stone, and no one saw the Stone. It was in the midst of our stones, like a man's head, such that a man's face could almost be seen in it. Then one clan of Quraysh said: We will place it. And others said: We will place it. They said: Let an arbitrator decide between you. They said: The first man to emerge from the mountain pass. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, came. They said: The trustworthy one has come to you. They told him, and he placed it in a garment, then he called their clans, and they took hold of its edges with him, and he, peace be upon him, placed it.

12.title: The first revelation and the prophethood of the Prophet, peace be upon him.
12.details: The first form of revelation the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) received was true visions in his sleep. He would not see a vision except it would come to pass like the breaking of the dawn. Then, he began to love solitude, so he would retreat to the cave of Hira and worship there. While he was in the cave, Gabriel (peace be upon him) came to him with the divine words: "{Read, [O Muhammad], by which your Lord created (1) Created man from a clinging substance. (2) Read, and your Lord is the most generous. (3) [He] who taught by the pen. (4) Taught man that which he knew not. (5)}" [Al-Alaq: 1-5]. He then recounted this to his wife Khadijah, who in turn told Warqah ibn Nawfal. Warqah confirmed it, saying, "This is the greatest law (Namus) that came to Moses." Then, the revelation ceased for a period. After that, Gabriel returned to him while he was sitting on a chair. The Prophet (peace be upon him) was frightened by him and returned to his family, saying, "Wrap me, wrap me." Then Allah the Almighty revealed: "{O you who enshrouds himself! (1) Arise and warn. (2) And your Lord magnify. (3) And your clothing purify. (4) And uncleanliness abandon. (5)}" [Al-Muddaththir: 1-5]. This marked the beginning of his prophethood and the command to convey the message.

13.title: The cessation of revelation from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.
13.details: The revelation ceased from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for a period of time, which distressed him and saddened him. Then Gabriel came to him with the chapter of Ad-Duha, his Lord swearing to him – and He is the One who honored him with what He honored him – that He had not forsaken him. Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih, from the narration of Jundub ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Gabriel was delayed in coming to the Prophet, peace be upon him. A woman from Quraysh – and she was Umm Jamil, Arwa bint Harb, the sister of Abu Sufyan and the wife of Abu Lahab – said: "His devil has delayed him." Then it was revealed: "By the morning brightness, and by the night when it settles, your Lord has not taken leave of you, nor has He detested you."

14.title: The first of people in faith in Allah and His Messenger.
14.details: The first to believe in Allah and His Messenger was Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, his wife, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, and Ali ibn Abi Talib. Then Zayd ibn Harithah, the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, embraced Islam. Through the invitation of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, Uthman ibn Affan, al-Zubayr ibn al-Awwam, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, and Talhah ibn Ubayd Allah, and Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf embraced Islam. Then Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah, Abu Salamah ibn Abd al-Asad, and Uthman ibn Maz'un embraced Islam, and then his brothers Qudamah and Abdullah, and his son al-Sa'ib ibn Uthman ibn Maz'un, Asma bint Abi Bakr al-Siddiq, and Aisha bint Abi Bakr al-Siddiq, who was young. Then Khalid ibn Sa'id ibn al-As embraced Islam, and his wife Aminah bint Bint Khalaf ibn As'ad al-Khuzaiyyah embraced Islam with him, and Bilal, Ammar ibn Yasir, and his mother Sumayyah, Suhayb ibn Sinan al-Numayri, known as al-Rumi, Amr ibn Absah al-Sulami, Amr ibn Sa'id ibn al-As, Sa'id ibn Zayd ibn Amr ibn Nufayl, and his wife Fatimah bint al-Khattab, the sister of Umar ibn al-Khattab, Umayr ibn Abi Waqqas, Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, and his brother Utbah ibn Mas'ud, Salit ibn Amr al-Amiri, Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah al-Makhzumi, and his wife Asma bint Salamah ibn Mukharribah al-Tamimiyyah, and Mas'ud ibn Rabi'ah ibn Amr al-Qari from the Banu al-Hun ibn Khuzaymah, who are al-Qarah, and Khunays ibn Hudhafah ibn Qays ibn Adi al-Sahmi, and Abdullah ibn Jahsh al-Asadi. The remaining early believers in the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, are: Ja'far ibn Abi Talib and his wife Asma bint Umays, Amir ibn Rabi'ah al-Anazi, from Anz ibn Wail, an ally of al-Khattab ibn Nufayl, Abu Ahmad ibn Jahsh al-A'ma, Hatib ibn al-Harith ibn Ma'mar al-Jumahi, and his wife Bint al-Mujallil al-Amiriyyah, Hattab ibn al-Harith, his brother, and his wife Fukayhah bint Yasar, and their brother Ma'mar ibn al-Harith ibn Ma'mar al-Jumahi, and al-Muttalib ibn Azhar ibn Abd Awf al-Zuhri, and his wife Ramlah bint Abi Awf al-Sahmiyyah, and al-Nahham, whose name is Nu'aym ibn Abdullah al-Adawi, and Amir ibn Fuheirah, a freed slave of Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, and Hatib ibn Amr ibn Shams ibn Abd Wadd al-Amiri, the brother of Salit ibn Amr, and Abu Hudhayfah ibn Utbah ibn Rabi'ah, whose name is Hisham ibn Utbah...

15.title: What the Companions suffered from the persecution of Quraysh.
15.details: The first seven to openly declare their Islam were: the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr, Ammar, his mother Sumayyah, Suhayb, Bilal, and Al-Miqdad. As for the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, God protected him through his uncle Abu Talib. As for Abu Bakr, his people protected him. As for the rest of them, the polytheists seized them, clothed them in iron armor, and roasted them in the sun. None of them escaped unharmed except that they complied with what the polytheists wanted and deceived them, except for Bilal. His soul was dear to him for the sake of God, the Almighty, and he was insignificant to his people. They seized him, gave him to the children, who paraded him through the valleys of Mecca, while he said: "One, one." They put a rope around his neck and handed him over to the children to play with, until it left a mark on his neck. Bilal belonged to some of the Banu Jumah. The one who took the lead in torturing him was Umayyah ibn Khalaf. He would take him out when the midday heat was intense, throw him on his back in the open ground of Mecca, then order a large rock to be placed on his chest. Then he would say to him: "You will remain like this until you die, or disbelieve in Muhammad and worship Al-Lat and Al-Uzza." While enduring this torture and affliction, he would say: "One, one." It was as if his torture and affliction only increased his faith upon faith. Abu Bakr felt compassion for him when he saw him one day in this extreme humiliation, so he bought him and set him free, and he also freed six others who were being tortured for Islam.

16.title: The Quraysh asked Abu Talib to restrain the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from them.
16.details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, called to God Almighty in all his states; by night and by day, in secret and in public. Nothing diverted him from this, no one turned him back, and no obstacle prevented him. He followed people to their gatherings, assemblies, and congregations, and during festivals and the pilgrimage seasons, calling to whoever he met, whether free or slave, weak or strong, rich or poor. The disbelievers of his people, the polytheists of Quraysh, oppressed him and those who followed him. Among the harshest of them towards him were his uncle Abu Lahab and his wife Umm Jamil, the firewood carrier – Arwa bint Harb bin Umayya, the sister of Abu Sufyan. His uncle Abu Talib bin Abdul Muttalib, however, was compassionate towards him, treated him well, defended him, and protected him, opposing his people in this matter, even though he remained on their religion. His continued adherence to his people's religion was part of God Almighty's wisdom and a protection He provided for His Messenger. For had Abu Talib embraced Islam, he would have had no standing or influence among the polytheists of Quraysh, nor would they have feared or respected him. The biographers narrated that Quraysh came to Abu Talib and said, "Your nephew has annoyed us in our gathering place and our mosque; stop him from us." He said, "O Aqil, go and bring Muhammad to me." So he brought him in the heat of the afternoon. When he came to them, Abu Talib said, "These cousins of yours claim that you annoy them in their gathering place and their mosque; so cease annoying them." The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, raised his gaze to the sky and said, "Do you see this sun?" They said, "Yes." He said, "Then I am no more able to abandon that than you are to be ignited by a flame from it." Abu Talib then said, "By God, my nephew has never lied. So go back."

17.title: The First Hijra to Abyssinia.
17.details: Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with her, said: When Makkah became too constricted for us, and the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, were harmed and persecuted, and they saw the afflictions and trials they faced in their religion, and that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, could not ward off that from them, while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was protected by his people and his uncle, and nothing he disliked reached him that befell his companions. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to them: Indeed, in the land of Abyssinia, there is a king under whom no one is wronged. So go to his land until Allah grants you relief and a way out of what you are in. So we went out to it until we gathered there, and we settled in the best of lands with the best of neighbors, secure in our religion, and we did not fear injustice from him... It is said that their departure to Abyssinia was in Rajab in the fifth year of the Prophetic Mission. Twelve men and four women of the Muslims migrated therein, including Uthman ibn Affan, and he was the first to leave, accompanied by his wife Ruqayyah, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

18.title: The Islam of Hamzah ibn Abd al-Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him.
18.details: In the latter part of the sixth year of his prophethood, Hamzah ibn Abd al-Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him, embraced Islam. The reason for his conversion was that Abu Jahl once passed by the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, near Safa, insulted him, and wronged him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, remained silent, not speaking to him. Then Abu Jahl struck him on the head with a stone, wounding him severely until blood flowed. He then left him and went to the gathering of Quraysh near the Kaaba and sat with them. A slave woman belonging to Abd Allah ibn Jud'an, in her dwelling on Safa, witnessed all of this. Hamzah arrived from hunting, his bow slung over his shoulder. The slave woman informed him of what she had seen Abu Jahl do. Hamzah became enraged and went out running, not stopping for anyone, intending to confront Abu Jahl if he met him. When he entered the Masjid, he stood over Abu Jahl and said, "Do you curse my nephew while I am of his religion!" Then he struck him with his bow, inflicting a terrible wound. Men from Banu Makhzum, Abu Jahl's tribe, rose up, and men from Banu Hashim, Hamzah's tribe, also rose up. Abu Jahl said, "Leave Abu Imarah alone! For I have insulted his nephew with an ugly insult." Ibn Ishaq said: "Then Hamzah returned to his house, and Satan came to him saying: 'You are the chief of Quraysh, yet you follow this apostate and abandon the religion of your forefathers. Death is better for you than what you have done.' Hamzah turned to himself and said: 'What have I done?! O Allah, if this is guidance, then make its confirmation in my heart. Otherwise, grant me a way out of what I have fallen into.' He spent a night such as he had never spent before, tormented by Satan's whispers, until morning. He then went to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and said: 'O nephew, I have fallen into a matter and do not know how to escape it. Is it guidance for someone like me to remain in a state I do not know whether it is right or grievous error? Tell me a story; I have longed, O nephew, for you to tell me.' The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, turned to him, reminded him, admonished him, warned him, and gave him good tidings. Allah then cast faith into his heart regarding what the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had said. He said: 'I bear witness that you are truthful, a true testimony. Reveal your religion, O nephew, for by Allah, I would not wish to have all that the sky covers if it meant I were to return to my former religion.' Thus, Hamzah's embrace of Islam, may Allah be pleased with him, began as the pride of a man who refused to see his kinsman insulted. Then Allah expanded his chest, and he held fast to the firmest handhold, and the Muslims were greatly strengthened by him!

19.title: The second migration to Abyssinia.
19.details: It reached the Emigrants in Abyssinia that Quraysh had embraced Islam, so they returned to Mecca in Shawwal of the same year they had emigrated. When they were a short distance from Mecca, and they learned the truth of the matter, those who wished returned to Abyssinia, and none of the rest entered Mecca except in secret, or under the protection of a man from Quraysh. Then the affliction and torture from Quraysh intensified against them and the Muslims, and their tribes intervened on their behalf. It was difficult for Quraysh to accept what they heard from the Negus about good protection, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saw no alternative but to advise his companions to emigrate to Abyssinia once again. The Muslims prepared for emigration again. Quraysh tried to thwart the second emigration operation, but the Muslims were faster and took refuge with the Negus of Abyssinia before they could be caught. Eighty-three men and eighteen or nineteen women emigrated. Quraysh sent Amr ibn al-As and Abdullah ibn Abi Rabi'ah, before they had embraced Islam, and sent with them valuable gifts for the Negus and his bishops. After they presented themselves to the Negus, they offered him the gifts and said to him: "O King, there have come to your land foolish youths who have abandoned the religion of their people and have not entered your religion, and they have brought a new religion that neither we nor you know. Their noble kinsmen, their fathers, uncles, and tribes, have sent us to you to return them to them, for they are more concerned about them and know best what they have criticized them for." And they rebuked them for it. The bishops said: "The King is right, so hand them over to them, so they can return them to their people and their land." The Negus sent for the Muslims and summoned them. They attended, having agreed to tell the truth, whatever the consequences. The Negus said to them: "What is this religion that you have abandoned your people for, and have not entered my religion or the religion of any of these communities?" Ja'far ibn Abi Talib – who was the spokesman for the Muslims – said: "O King, we were a people of ignorance; we worshipped idols, ate carrion, committed indecencies, severed ties of kinship, mistreated neighbors, and the strong among us devoured the weak." He then enumerated the virtues of what the Prophet, peace be upon him, had brought them, and said: "So we believed him, and we accepted him, and we followed him in the religion of Allah that he brought us. We worshipped Allah alone, associating nothing with Him. We forbade what was forbidden to us, and permitted what was permitted to us. Then our people attacked us, tortured us, and tried to turn us away from our religion, so that we would return to the worship of idols instead of the worship of Allah Almighty, and so that we would permit what we used to permit of evils. When they oppressed us, wronged us, made things difficult for us, and prevented us from practicing our religion, we came to your land, and we chose you over all others, and desired your protection, and hoped that we would not be wronged in your presence, O King." The Negus said to him: "Do you have anything of what he brought from God?" Ja'far said: "Yes." The Negus said: "Then recite it to me." So he recited to him a portion of Surah Maryam. The Negus wept until his beard was wet, and his bishops wept until their scriptures were wet when they heard what he recited to them. Then the Negus said to them: "Indeed, this and what Jesus brought comes from the same source. Go, for by God, I will not hand them over to you, nor will they be able to." (addressing Amr ibn al-As and his companion). They left, and when they left, Amr ibn al-As said to Abdullah ibn Abi Rabi'ah: "By God, tomorrow I will go to him about them with something that will uproot their existence." Abdullah ibn Abi Rabi'ah said to him: "Do not do that, for they have kinship ties, even if they have opposed us." But Amr insisted on his opinion. The next day, he said to the Negus: "O King, they say something great about Jesus, son of Mary." The Negus sent for them and asked them about their belief concerning the Messiah. They were frightened, but they agreed to tell the truth, whatever the consequences. When they entered and he asked them, Ja'far said: "We say about him what our Prophet, peace be upon him, brought us: He is the servant of Allah, His Messenger, His Spirit, and His Word, which He cast to Mary, the pure virgin." The Negus took a twig from the ground and said: "By God, Jesus, son of Mary, did not exceed what you have said with this twig." His bishops grumbled, and he said: "Even if you grumble." Then he said to the Muslims: "Go, you are safe in my land." (Al-Shuyum means safe in the Abyssinian language). Whoever insults you will pay a fine, whoever insults you will pay a fine, whoever insults you will pay a fine. I would not want a mountain of gold if it meant I had harmed one of you. (Al-Dabr means mountain in the Abyssinian language). Then he said to his retinue: "Return their gifts to them, for I have no need of them. By God, Allah did not take bribes from me when He returned my kingdom to me, so I would take bribes in this matter. And He did not obey people concerning me, so I would obey them concerning Him." Umm Salamah said: "So they left him, disgraced and with their mission rejected, and we stayed with him in the best of abodes, with the best of neighbors."

20.title: The Islam of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him.
20.details: Al-Tirmidhi narrated in his Sunan, on the authority of Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both), that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "O Allah, strengthen Islam with the more beloved of these two men to You: Abu Jahl or Umar bin Al-Khattab." He said: "And Umar was the more beloved of them to Him." The biographers narrated that Umar once went out, girded with his sword, intending to eliminate the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). He met a man who asked him, "Where are you going, Umar?" He replied, "I intend to kill Muhammad." The man said, "How can you be safe from Banu Hashim and Banu Zuhrah if you kill Muhammad?" Umar said to him, "I see that you have become a Sabian and abandoned the religion you were upon." He replied, "Shall I not guide you to something astonishing, O Umar? Your sister and your brother-in-law have become Sabians and abandoned the religion you are upon." So Umar went to them, and Khabbab bin Al-Aratt was with them, holding a parchment containing Surah Taha, reading it to them. When Khabbab heard Umar's footsteps, he hid in the house, and Umar's sister, Fatima, concealed the parchment. Umar had heard Khabbab's recitation to them as he approached the house. When he entered, he asked, "What is this murmuring I heard from you?" They replied, "Nothing but conversation we were having amongst ourselves." He said, "Perhaps you have both become Sabians?" His brother-in-law said to him, "O Umar, what if the truth is in a religion other than yours?" Umar lunged at his brother-in-law and beat him severely. His sister came and pulled him away from her husband, and he struck her with his hand, causing her face to bleed. She said, in anger, "O Umar, if the truth is in a religion other than yours, I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah." When Umar despaired and saw the blood on his sister's face, he regretted it and felt ashamed. He said, "Give me this book you have so I can read it." His sister said, "You are impure, and none shall touch it except the purified. Get up and perform ghusl." So he got up and performed ghusl, then took the book and read: "In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful." He said, "These are beautiful and pure names." Then he read Taha until he reached the verse: "Indeed, I am Allah. There is no god but I, so worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance." He said, "How beautiful and noble is this speech! Guide me to Muhammad." He went to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and embraced Islam in his presence. Then the Muslims went out with him in two rows until they entered the Masjid. When the Quraysh saw them, they were overcome with a sadness they had never experienced before.

21.title: The Islam of Tufayl ibn Amr al-Dawsi, may Allah be pleased with him.
21.details:
The Quraysh used to warn people against listening to the Prophet, peace be upon him. When Tufayl ibn Amr arrived in Mecca, men from Quraysh approached him. Tufayl was a noble man, a poet, and intelligent. They said to him: "O Tufayl, you have come to our land, and this man who is among us has caused us great trouble. He has divided our community and scattered our affairs. His words are like magic that separates a man from his father, a man from his brother, and a man from his wife. We fear for you and your people what has befallen us. So do not speak to him, nor listen to anything he says."

He said: "By God, they continued to persuade me until I resolved not to listen to him or speak to him. When I went to the mosque, I stuffed cotton into my ears, fearing that some of his words might reach me, as I did not want to hear them. I went to the mosque and saw the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, praying by the Kaaba. I stood near him, but God willed that I should hear some of his words. I heard beautiful speech. I said to myself: Woe is me! By God, I am an intelligent and poetic man, and I can distinguish the good from the bad. What prevents me from listening to what this man says? If what he brings is good, I will accept it, and if it is bad, I will abandon it."

He said: "I stayed until the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, went to his house. I followed him, and when he entered his house, I entered after him. I said: 'O Muhammad, your people told me such and such, and they kept frightening me about you until I plugged my ears with cotton so as not to hear your words. Then God willed that I should hear your words, and I heard beautiful speech. Present your message to me.'"

He said: "The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, presented Islam to me and recited the Quran to me. By God, I have never heard more beautiful speech, nor a more just command. So I embraced Islam and bore witness to the truth. I said: 'O Prophet of God, I am a man who is obeyed by my people, and I am returning to them to call them to Islam. Pray to God to grant me a sign that will help me in calling them to it.' He said: 'O God, grant him a sign.'"

He said: "I went out to my people. When I reached a mountain pass that overlooked the settled people, a light appeared between my eyes like a lamp. I said: 'O God, not on my face. I fear they will think it is a disfigurement on my face for leaving their religion.' He said: 'It moved and fell on the head of my staff.' He said: 'The people below began to see that light on my staff like a hanging lamp, as I descended to them from the pass. When I reached them, I stayed among them.'

When I dismounted, my father, an old man, came to me. I said: 'Stay away from me, my father. I am not of you, and you are not of me.' He said: 'Why, my son?' I said: 'I have embraced Islam and followed the religion of Muhammad, peace be upon him.' He said: 'My son, my religion is your religion.' I said: 'Go and wash yourself and purify your clothes, then come, and I will teach you what I have learned.' He went, washed himself, purified his clothes, then came, and I presented Islam to him, and he embraced Islam.

Then my wife came to me. I said: 'Stay away from me. I am not of you, and you are not of me.' She said: 'Why? May my father and mother be sacrificed for you.' I said: 'Islam has separated me from you, and I have followed the religion of Muhammad, peace be upon him.' She said: 'My religion is your religion.' I said: 'Go and purify yourself.' She went and washed herself, then came, and I presented Islam to her, and she embraced Islam.

Then I called Daws to Islam, but they were slow to respond. Then I came to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, in Mecca, and said to him: 'O Prophet of God, fornication has overcome Daws. Pray to God against them.' He said: 'O God, guide Daws. Return to your people and call them, and be gentle with them.'"

He said: "I continued in the land of Daws, calling them to Islam, until the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, migrated to Medina, and Badr, Uhud, and the Trench passed. Then I came to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, with those of my people who had embraced Islam with me, while the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, was in Khaybar. I arrived in Medina with seventy or eighty households from Daws, then we joined the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, in Khaybar, and he gave us a share along with the Muslims."

He continued to be with the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, until God granted him victory in Mecca. He was with him in Medina until God took his soul. When the Arabs apostatized, he went out with the Muslims and marched with them until they finished with Tulayha and all the land of Najd. Then he marched with the Muslims to Yamama and was martyred there.

22.title: The Quraish siege of the Muslims in the Shi'b Abi Talib.
22.details: When Quraysh resolved to kill the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, all of Banu Abd al-Muttalib agreed to take the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, into their valley and protect him there. It is narrated from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said on the morning of the Day of Sacrifice, while he was in Mina: "Tomorrow we will descend in the valley of Banu Kinanah, where they swore against disbelief." This refers to al-Muhassab, and that is because Quraysh and Kinanah allied against Banu Hashim and Banu Abd al-Muttalib, or Banu al-Muttalib, to not marry them or trade with them until they handed over the Prophet, peace be upon him, to them. So they all entered the valley, both the Muslims and the disbelievers among them. The polytheists united in their decision not to sit with them, associate with them, trade with them, or enter their homes, until they handed over the Messenger of Allah for killing. They wrote a document to that effect. Banu Hashim remained in their valley for three years, and the affliction, hardship, and hunger intensified upon them. When three years had passed, some men from Quraysh blamed each other for what had happened and agreed to annul the document. Thus, the boycott ended.

23.title: The Quraysh's breach of the Charter of Medina.
23.details: After two or three years of the unjust siege in the valley of Abu Talib, the document was annulled and the siege was lifted. This was because the Quraysh were divided between those who were pleased with this pact and those who disliked it. So, those who disliked it sought to annul the document. The one who took the initiative was Hisham ibn Amr from Banu Amer ibn Lu'ayy. He used to secretly supply the Banu Hashim in the valley with food at night. He went to Zuhayr ibn Abi Umayyah al-Makhzumi, whose mother was Atikah bint Abd al-Muttalib, and said: "O Zuhayr, are you content to eat food and drink, while your maternal uncles are in the state you know?" He replied: "Woe to you, what can I do? I am only one man. By God, if I had another man with me, I would stand up to annul it." He said: "You have found a man." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "I am." Zuhayr then said to him: "Find us a third man." So, he went to Al-Mu'tim ibn Adi, reminded him of the kinship ties between Banu Hashim and Banu al-Muttalib, sons of Abd Manaf, and blamed him for agreeing with the Quraysh on this injustice. Al-Mu'tim said: "Woe to you, what can I do? I am only one man." He said: "You have found a second." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "I am." He said: "Find us a third." He said: "I have done so." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "Zuhayr ibn Abi Umayyah." He said: "Find us a fourth." So, he went to Abu al-Bukhtari ibn Hisham and said to him much the same as he had said to Al-Mu'tim. He asked: "Is there anyone who will help with this?" He said: "Yes." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "Zuhayr ibn Abi Umayyah, Al-Mu'tim ibn Adi, and I am with you." He said: "Find us a fifth." So, he went to Zam'ah ibn al-Aswad ibn al-Muttalib ibn Asad, spoke to him, and reminded him of their kinship and their rights. He asked him: "Is there anyone else for this matter you are calling me to?" He said: "Yes." Then he named the people to him. They gathered at al-Hajun and pledged to stand up to annul the document. Zuhayr said: "I will start with you, so I will be the first to speak." When morning came, they went to their assemblies. Zuhayr went, wearing a garment, circled the Kaaba seven times, then turned to the people and said: "O people of Mecca, do we eat food and wear clothes while Banu Hashim are perishing, and no one buys from or sells to them? By God, I will not sit down until this cutting and unjust document is torn." Abu Jahl, who was in a corner of the mosque, said: "You lie, by God, it will not be torn." Zam'ah ibn al-Aswad said: "By God, you are the liar. We did not agree to its writing when it was written." Abu al-Bukhtari said: "Zam'ah has spoken the truth. We do not agree with what was written in it, nor do we acknowledge it." Al-Mu'tim ibn Adi said: "You both have spoken the truth, and whoever says otherwise is a liar. We absolve ourselves before God of it and of what was written in it." Hisham ibn Amr said something similar. Abu Jahl then said: "This is a matter decided at night, and discussed elsewhere." Abu Talib was sitting in a corner of the mosque. They came to them because God had informed His Messenger, peace be upon him, about the document and that He had sent the termite upon it, and it had eaten everything in it of injustice, severance, and oppression, except for the mention of God, the Mighty and Majestic. He informed his uncle, who went to the Quraysh and told them that his nephew had said such and such. He said: "If he is lying, we will leave you to deal with him, and if he is telling the truth, you will cease your severance and injustice towards us." They said: "You have been fair." After the discussion between the people and Abu Jahl, Al-Mu'tim stood up to tear the document, and found that the termite had eaten it except for "(In Your Name, O Allah)," and whatever mention of God was in it, it had not eaten. Then the document was annulled, and the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, and those with him, came out of the valley. The polytheists had seen a great sign of his prophethood, but they were as God described them: "(And if they see a sign, they turn away and say, 'This is continuous magic.')" They turned away from this sign and increased their disbelief.

24.title: The passing of the Mother of the Believers, Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her.
24.details: She is Khadijah, daughter of Khuwaylid, son of Asad, son of Abd al-Uzza, son of Qusai, son of Kilab, among the best women of this world. Gabriel came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: "O Messenger of Allah, Khadijah has come to you with a vessel containing food, or drink. When she comes to you, convey to her greetings from her Lord and from me, and give her glad tidings of a house in Paradise made of reeds, wherein there will be no noise nor toil." Khadijah was the first to embrace Islam with the Prophet, peace be upon him. She believed in him when people disbelieved, she sheltered him when people rejected him, and she affirmed him when people denied him. Allah blessed him with children through her: Al-Qasim, At-Tayyib, and At-Tahir, who died in infancy, and Ruqayyah, Zaynab, Umm Kulthum, and Fatimah. May Allah be pleased with her. She passed away, along with Abu Talib, in the same year. The calamities followed one another for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with their deaths. Khadijah was a minister of truth for Islam, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, found solace in her. "Khadijah passed away three years before the Prophet, peace be upon him, migrated to Medina. He remained for two years, or close to that, and married Aisha when she was six years old, and then consummated the marriage when she was nine years old." The Mother of the Believers, Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her, passed away in Mecca and was buried in Al-Hajun.

25.title: The departure of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to Ta'if.
25.details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to Taif, which is about sixty miles from Mecca. He walked there and back on foot, accompanied by his freed slave Zayd ibn Harithah. Whenever he passed a tribe on the way, he invited them to Islam, but none responded. When he reached Taif, he approached its leaders and invited them, but they did not respond. He stayed among the people of Taif for ten days, visiting every one of their nobles and speaking to them. They told him, "Leave our land." They incited their fools against him. When he intended to leave, the fools and their slaves followed him, insulting and shouting at him, until the people gathered against him. They formed two lines and began to stone him and hurl insults at him, and they stoned his heels until his sandals were stained with blood. Zayd ibn Harithah protected him with his own body, sustaining a head wound. The fools continued to harass him until they forced him to take refuge in a garden belonging to Utbah and Shaybah, sons of Rabi'ah, three miles from Taif. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, returned on the road to Mecca after leaving the garden, dejected and sorrowful, with a broken heart. When he reached Qarn al-Manazil, God sent Gabriel to him, accompanied by the Angel of the Mountains, asking if he wished to crush the people of Mecca between the two mountains. The Prophet, peace be upon him, replied, "Rather, I hope that God, the Almighty, will bring forth from their loins those who worship God, the Almighty, alone, associating nothing with Him." In this response given by the Messenger, peace be upon him, his unique character and his great moral disposition are evident.

26.title: The Islam of the Jinn and their coming in delegations to the Prophet, peace be upon him.
26.details: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, returned from Ta'if to Mecca, he stopped at Nakhlah. In the middle of the night, he rose to pray. The group of jinn, whom Allah the Almighty mentioned, passed by him. They were seven jinn from the people of Nasibin. They listened to the recitation of the Messenger, peace be upon him. When he finished his prayer, they turned back to their people as warners, having believed and responded to what they heard. Regarding them, Allah the Almighty revealed: "And [mention, O Muhammad], when We directed to you a few of the jinn to listen to the Quran. When they attended it, they said, 'Be silent.' And when it was finished, they went back to their people, warning. They said, 'O our people, indeed we have heard a Book revealed after Moses, confirming that which was before it, guiding to the truth and to a straight path. O our people, respond to the one who calls to Allah and believe in him. He will forgive for you your sins and protect you from a painful punishment. And whoever does not respond to the one who calls to Allah will not cause failure on earth, and he will not have besides Him protectors. Those are in clear error.'" [Al-Ahqaf]. And after several months from the meeting of the first delegation of jinn with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the second delegation came, eager to see the beloved chosen one, peace be upon him, and to listen to the words of the Lord of the worlds.

27.title: The death of Abu Talib, the uncle of the Prophet, peace be upon him.
27.details: After the illness intensified for Abu Talib, the uncle of the Prophet, peace be upon him, who had taken care of him when he was young, supported him when he was older, aided him in his call, and protected him from the harm of the polytheists, the Prophet, peace be upon him, entered upon him. Abu Jahl was with him. The Prophet said: "O uncle, say: 'There is no god but Allah,' a word for which I will argue on your behalf before Allah." Abu Jahl and Abdullah ibn Abi Umayyah said: "O Abu Talib, do you turn away from the religion of Abdul Muttalib?" They continued to speak to him until the last thing he said to them was: "On the religion of Abdul Muttalib." Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "I will surely ask forgiveness for you as long as I am not forbidden." Then it was revealed: {It is not for the Prophet and those who have believed to ask forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they were relatives, after it has become clear to them that they are companions of the Hellfire.} And it was revealed: {Indeed, you do not guide whom you love.} Abu Talib had been the fortress behind which the Prophet, peace be upon him, took refuge from the attacks of the prominent and the foolish, but he remained upon the religion of the elders among his forefathers, and thus did not succeed.

28.title: The marriage of the Prophet, peace be upon him, to Sawdah bint Zam'ah, may Allah be pleased with her.
28.details: After the death of the Mother of the Believers, Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her, who was one of Allah's great blessings upon the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, married Sawdah bint Zam'ah ibn Qays ibn 'Abd Shams ibn 'Abd Wudd ibn Nasr ibn Malik ibn Hisl ibn 'Amir ibn Lu'ayy, al-Qurashiyyah. He married her in Mecca before the Hijra. She was among those who embraced Islam early and migrated the second migration to Abyssinia. Her husband was al-Sakran ibn 'Amr, who had embraced Islam and migrated with her. He died in the land of Abyssinia, or after returning to Mecca. When her waiting period ended, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, proposed to her and married her. She was the first woman he married after the death of Khadijah. She was in her sixth decade of life at that time. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, intended to divorce her, she reconciled with him by gifting her turn to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, so he kept her. She did not bear him any children until he passed away, peace be upon him.

29.title: The beginning of the Ansar's entry into Islam.
29.details: When Allah, the Almighty, willed to manifest His religion, honor His Prophet, peace be upon him, and fulfill His promise to him, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out during the Hajj season, presenting himself to the Arab tribes, as he had done in every season. While he was at Al-Aqabah, he met a group of Khazraj whom Allah intended good for. He asked them, "Who are you?" They replied, "A group of Khazraj." He asked, "Are you allies of the Jews?" They said, "Yes." He then asked, "Will you sit with me so I may speak to you?" They replied, "Certainly." So they sat with him, and he invited them to Allah, the Almighty, presented Islam to them, and recited the Quran to them. Among the favors Allah bestowed upon them in Islam was that the Jews were with them in their land, and they used to warn them of the imminent appearance of a prophet whom they would follow, and then with him, they would kill the Arabs with a decisive victory. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, spoke to them and invited them to Allah, some of them said to each other, "O people, know that, by Allah, this is the prophet whom the Jews warned you about. So do not let them get to him before you." They responded to his invitation and said to him, "We have left our people, and there is no people between us who have as much enmity and conflict as they do. Perhaps Allah will unite them with you. We will return and invite them to your cause, and present to them what we have accepted from this religion. If Allah unites them with you, no man will be more honored than you." Then they departed, returning to their land, having believed and testified. When they arrived in Medina to their people, they spoke of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and invited them to Islam until it spread among them. There was no house among the Ansar that did not have mention of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him.

30.title: The marriage of the Prophet to Aisha, daughter of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with them both.
30.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, married Aisha the Truthful, may Allah be pleased with her, when she was six years old, and consummated the marriage with her in Medina in Shawwal in the second year of the Hijra, when she was nine years old. She was the most favored and beloved of his wives to him, and he did not marry any virgin other than her.

31.title: The First Pledge of al-Aqabah
31.details: It was narrated from `Ubadah ibn al-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, one of the chieftains on the night of `Aqabah, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, his family, and his companions, said while a group of his companions were around him: "Pledge allegiance to me on the condition that you will not associate anything with Allah, will not steal, will not commit adultery, will not kill your children, will not utter slander which you have forged between your hands and your feet, and will not disobey in what is right. Whoever among you fulfills this, his reward is with Allah. Whoever commits any of these acts and is punished in this world, it will be an expiation for him. Whoever commits any of these acts and Allah conceals him, then it is up to Allah; if He wills, He will forgive him, and if He wills, He will punish him." He said: "So we pledged allegiance to him on that basis."

32.title: The Night Journey, the Ascension, and the Obligation of the Five Daily Prayers.
32.details: In this great incident, the Prophet, peace be upon him, saw the prophets, and saw the Lote tree of the Utmost Boundary, and other great signs. In it, the five daily prayers were ordained, and this is something agreed upon by the narrations of the two Sahih collections. The Quraysh denied the occurrence of the incident of the Night Journey and Ascension, and this is also something agreed upon by the narrations of the two Sahih collections. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "I saw myself in the Hijr, and the Quraysh were asking me about my Night Journey. They asked me about things from Jerusalem that I had not retained. So I was distressed with a distress the like of which I had never experienced." He said: "Then Allah raised it for me to look at. Whatever they asked me about, I informed them. I saw myself in a gathering of prophets. There was Moses, standing and praying. He was a man of strong build, curly-haired, as if from the men of Shinū'ah. And there was Jesus, son of Mary, peace be upon him, standing and praying. The person most resembling him in likeness was Urwah ibn Mas'ud al-Thaqafi. And there was Abraham, peace be upon him, standing and praying. The person most resembling him was your companion" - meaning himself. Then the time for prayer came, and I led them in prayer. When I finished the prayer, someone said: "O Muhammad, this is Malik, the keeper of Hellfire. Greet him." So I turned to him, and he greeted me first."

33.title: The Hijra of Abu Salamah and Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with them.
33.details: Abu Salamah Abdullah ibn Abd al-Asad was the first of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, among the Emigrants from Quraysh from Banu Makhzum, to migrate to Medina. His migration took place after the first pledge of Aqabah and before the second pledge of Aqabah, when the Quraysh had harmed him after his return from Abyssinia. He resolved to return there, and then it reached him that they had brothers in Medina, so he decided to migrate to them. Umm Salamah said: When Abu Salamah decided to go to Medina, he prepared a camel for me, then placed me upon it, and put my son Salamah ibn Abi Salamah in my lap. Then he went out leading my camel, and the Banu Abd al-Asad went with him, while the Banu Mughirah detained me with them, and my husband Abu Salamah went to Medina. She said: So I was separated from my son and my husband. She said: I used to go out every morning and sit in al-Abṭaḥ, and I would not stop crying until evening, for a year or close to it, until a man from my paternal uncles, one of the Banu Mughirah, passed by me and saw my state and took pity on me. He said to the Banu Mughirah: Will you not release this poor woman? Have you separated her from her husband and her child? She said: They then said to me: Go to your husband if you wish. She said: At that, the Banu Abd al-Asad returned my son to me. She said: So I prepared my camel, then took my son and placed him in my lap, then I set out to go to my husband in Medina. She said: And I had no one from God's creation with me, until when I reached al-Tan'im, I met Uthman ibn Talhah ibn Abi Talhah, brother of Banu Abd al-Dar. He said: Where are you going, O daughter of Umm Ayyah? I said: I am going to my husband in Medina. He said: Do you not have anyone with you? I said: I have no one with me except Allah and this son of mine. He said: By Allah, you are not to be left behind. He took the camel's reins and set out with me, hurrying me along. By Allah, I have never accompanied any man among the Arabs whom I considered more honorable than him. When he reached a stopping place, he would make the camel kneel, then he would move away from me until I dismounted. When I dismounted, he would move his camel away, unload it, then tie it to a tree. Then he would move to a tree and lie down beneath it. When it was time to depart, he would stand by my camel, prepare it, then move away from me and say: Mount. When I mounted and settled on my camel, he would come, take the reins, and lead me until he dismounted me. He continued to do this for me until he brought me to Medina. When he saw the village of Banu Amr ibn Awf in Quba, he said: Your husband is in this village. Abu Salamah was residing there, so enter it with the blessing of Allah. Then he returned to Mecca. Umm Salamah used to say: I do not know of any family in Islam that suffered what the family of Abu Salamah suffered, and I have never seen a companion more honorable than Uthman ibn Talhah. Uthman ibn Talhah ibn Abi Talhah al-Abdari embraced Islam after Hudaybiyyah.

34.title: The spread of Islam in Yathrib after the First Pledge of Aqabah.
34.details: After the first Pledge of Aqabah, the Ansar wrote to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, asking him to send someone to lead them in prayer and teach them the Quran. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent them Mus'ab ibn Umayr. He stayed as a guest of Sa'd ibn Zurarah and began to call people to Islam. Islam spread among the people of Yathrib until there was no house in Yathrib that did not have a Muslim man or woman. Among those who embraced Islam at his hands were the two chiefs of the Aws, Sa'd ibn Mu'adh and Usayd ibn Hudayr.

35.title: The Second Pledge of al-Aqabah.
35.details: Jabir reported: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, stayed in Mecca for ten years, approaching people in their dwellings, at 'Ukaz, Majanna, and during the seasons in Mina, saying: 'Who will host me? Who will support me so that I may convey the message of my Lord, and for him shall be Paradise?' It reached the point that a man would come from Yemen or from Muzar, and his people would say to him: 'Beware of the Qurayshite youth, lest he tempt you.' He would walk among their men, and they would point at him with their fingers. Until Allah sent us from Yathrib to him, so we hosted him and believed in him. A man from us would go out, believe in him, and teach him the Quran. Then he would return to his family, and they would embrace Islam with his Islam, until there was no house among the houses of the Ansar but had a group of Muslims openly declaring Islam. Then we all consulted and said: 'How long shall we leave the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to be driven away in the mountains of Mecca and live in fear?' So seventy men from us set out to him, until they met him during the season, and we promised him at the valley of al-'Aqabah. We gathered around him, a man or two at a time, until we were complete. We said: 'O Messenger of Allah, we will pledge allegiance to you.' He said: 'You will pledge allegiance to me on hearing and obeying, in times of eagerness and reluctance, on spending in times of hardship and ease, on enjoining good and forbidding evil, and that you speak the truth about Allah, fearing no blame from any blamer. And that you support me, so you protect me when I come to you, just as you protect yourselves, your wives, and your children, and for you shall be Paradise.' He said: 'So we stood up to him and pledged allegiance. Al-As'ad ibn Zurarah, who was one of the youngest, took his hand and said: 'Hold on, O people of Yathrib. We did not travel on the backs of camels except that we knew he was the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. And his departure today means the separation of all Arabs, the killing of your best men, and that swords will bite you. So if you are people who can endure this, your reward is with Allah. But if you fear weakness in yourselves, then make it clear, and that is an excuse for you with Allah.' They said: 'Remove it from us, O As'ad. By Allah, we will never abandon this pledge, nor will we ever break it.' He said: 'So we stood up to him and pledged allegiance, and he took our pledge and stipulated conditions, and in return for that, he promised us Paradise.'"

36.title: The miracle of the splitting of the moon.
36.details: From Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The moon was split into two parts during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Bear witness." And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the people of Mecca asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to show them a sign, so he showed them the moon split into two parts, until they saw Hira between them. And in Sahih Muslim, from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, who said: The moon was split into two halves during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The mountain covered one half, and one half was above the mountain. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "O Allah, bear witness." It is widely known that the splitting of the moon occurred only once. As for what is mentioned in one of the narrations of Muslim: (...so he showed them the splitting of the moon twice), scholars have responded to it. Ibn al-Qayyim, Ibn Hajar, and others have favored that it occurred only once.

37.title: The Islam of Abdullah ibn Salam, may Allah be pleased with him.
37.details: Abdullah ibn Salam, may Allah be pleased with him, was a distinguished scholar among the Jews, a learned man. He said: "When I heard about the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, I recognized his description, his name, and the time we were expecting him. I kept this to myself, remaining silent about it, until the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, arrived in Medina. When he stayed in Quba, among the Banu Amr ibn Awf, a man came and informed me of his arrival. I was at the top of my palm tree, working on it, and my aunt, Khālidah bint al-Ḥārith, was sitting below me. When I heard the news of the Messenger of Allah's arrival, peace and blessings be upon him, I exclaimed 'Allahu Akbar!' My aunt said to me upon hearing my exclamation: 'May Allah disappoint you! By God, if you had heard of Moses son of Imran arriving, you would not have done more!' I said to her: 'O aunt, he is, by God, the brother of Moses son of Imran, and on his religion, he has been sent with what he was sent with.' She said: 'O my nephew, is he the Prophet we were told would be sent with the coming of the Hour?' I said to her: 'Yes.' She said: 'Then that is he.' Then I went out to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and embraced Islam. Then I returned to my household and commanded them, and they embraced Islam. I concealed my Islam from the Jews. Then I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said to him: 'O Messenger of Allah, the Jews are a deceitful people, and I would like you to admit me into one of your houses, and conceal me from them, and then ask them about me, so that they may tell you what I am like among them, before they know of my Islam. For if they know of it, they will deceive me and criticize me.' So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, admitted me into one of his houses, and they came to him and spoke with him and questioned him. Then he said to them: 'What kind of man is Abdullah ibn Salam among you?' They said: 'Our master and son of our master, our scholar and learned man.' When they finished speaking, I came out to them and said: 'O assembly of Jews, fear Allah and accept what has come to you. For by God, you know that he is indeed the Messenger of Allah. You find him written among you in the Torah by his name and description. I bear witness that he is the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and I believe in him, and I affirm him, and I recognize him.' They said: 'You lie.' Then they attacked me. I said to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Did I not tell you, O Messenger of Allah, that they are a deceitful people, a people of treachery, lies, and wickedness!' Then I revealed my Islam and the Islam of my household, and my aunt Khālidah bint al-Ḥārith embraced Islam, and her Islam was good."

38.title: The Prophet's peace be upon him treaty with the Jews.
38.details: Ibn Ishaq said: "The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, wrote a document between the Emigrants and the Helpers, and in it he made peace with the Jews, covenanted with them, confirmed them in their religion and their property, and stipulated conditions for them and they for him." This was when they refused to follow him, and this was before permission was given to fight and to take the jizya from those who refused Islam. Indeed, the majority of them refused except for disbelief. They were three tribes: Banu Qaynuqa, Banu an-Nadir, and Banu Qurayza. All three fought him. He showed favor to Banu Qaynuqa, exiled Banu an-Nadir, and killed Banu Qurayza, taking their descendants captive. Surah Al-Hashr was revealed concerning Banu an-Nadir, and Surah Al-Ahzab concerning Banu Qurayza.

39.title: The permissibility of the Adhan.
39.details: Ibn Umar narrated that when the Muslims arrived in Medina, they used to gather and wait for the prayers, but no one called them to prayer. One day, they discussed this matter. Some of them said, "Let's take a bell like the Christians' bell." Others said, "Let's take a horn like the Jews' horn." Abdullah bin Zayd said: "When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered that a bell be made to strike for people to gather for prayer, a man carrying a bell in his hand passed by me while I was asleep. I said to him, 'O servant of Allah, will you sell the bell?' He asked, 'What will you do with it?' I replied, 'We will call people to prayer with it.' He said, 'Shall I not guide you to something better than that?' I said, 'Yes.' He then said: 'You should say: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illallah, Ash-hadu an la ilaha illallah. Ash-hadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah, Ash-hadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'alas-Salah, Hayya 'alas-Salah. Hayya 'alal-Falah, Hayya 'alal-Falah. Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illallah.' Then he moved a short distance away from me and said: 'And when you commence the prayer, say: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illallah. Ash-hadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'alas-Salah. Hayya 'alal-Falah. Qad qamatis-Salah, Qad qamatis-Salah. Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illallah.'" When morning came, I went to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and told him what I had seen. He said, "This is a true vision, God willing. Go with Bilal and tell him what you saw, and let him call to prayer with it, for he has a more resonant voice than you." So I went with Bilal and told him what I had seen, and he called to prayer with it. Umar bin Al-Khattab heard this while he was in his house. He came out dragging his cloak, saying, "By Him Who sent you with the truth, O Messenger of Allah, I saw the same as he saw." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said, "Praise be to Allah."

40.title: The Hijra of the Companions to Medina.
40.details: When the Pledge of Al-Aqabah was completed, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered those who were with him to migrate to Medina. So they left in groups. Among the first to migrate after the second Al-Aqabah was Mus'ab ibn Umayr, then 'Amir ibn Rab'ah, an ally of Banu 'Adi ibn Ka'b, with his wife Layla bint Abi Hathmah ibn Ghanam. Then 'Abdullah ibn Jahsh with his family and his brother 'Abd ibn Jahsh, Abu Ahmad, who was blind. Their dwelling and the dwelling of Abu Salamah were in Quba' among Banu 'Amr ibn 'Awf. When all of Banu Jahsh migrated with their women, Abu Sufyan seized their homes and took possession of them. 'Abdullah ibn Jahsh mentioned this to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when he learned of it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to him: "Are you not pleased, O 'Abdullah, that Allah will give you a house in Paradise better than it?" He said: "Yes." He said: "Then it is for you." When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, conquered Mecca, Abu Ahmad spoke to him about their homes. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, delayed him. The people said to Abu Ahmad: "O Abu Ahmad, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, dislikes that you should return concerning something that befell you for the sake of Allah." So he refrained from speaking to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. And Banu Ghanam ibn Duudan were people of Islam who had all migrated to Medina. Then 'Umar ibn Al-Khattab and 'Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah migrated with twenty riders and arrived in Medina. Hisham ibn Al-'As ibn Wa'il had embraced Islam and had agreed with 'Umar ibn Al-Khattab to migrate with him, saying: "You will find me or I will find you at the watering place of Banu Ghifar." His people realized this and prevented him from migrating. Then Abu Jahl and Al-Harith ibn Hisham left until they arrived in Medina while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was in Mecca.
