They spoke to 'Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah, who was their brother by their mother and their cousin, and informed him that their mother had vowed not to wash her head or seek shade until she saw him. His heart softened, and he believed them and set out returning with them. They then bound him on the road and brought him to Mecca, in broad daylight, bound. Then they said: "O people of Mecca, do this to your foolish ones as we have done to our foolish one." So they imprisoned him there until Allah, the Exalted, delivered him afterward through the supplication of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in the Qunut of prayer: "O Allah, save Al-Walid ibn Al-Walid, and Salamah ibn Hisham, and 'Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah." When Suhayb ibn Sinan intended to migrate, the disbelievers of Quraysh said to him: "You came to us as a penniless, insignificant person, and your wealth increased among us, and you reached what you reached, and now you want to leave with your wealth and yourself. No, by Allah, that will not happen." Suhayb said to them: "What if I give you all my wealth, will you let me go?" They said: "Yes." He said: "Then I have given it to you." This reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and he said: "Suhayb has profited, Suhayb has profited." Then the emigrants continued to migrate to Medina until the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, migrated.

41.title: The polytheists' meeting in Dar al-Nadwah and their agreement to kill the Prophet, peace be upon him.
41.details: When the polytheists saw that the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had prepared and departed, carrying and driving their families, children, and wealth to the Aws and Khazraj in Yathrib, they were overcome by gloom and sorrow, and anxiety and worry besieged them. The chieftains of Mecca gathered in Dar al-Nadwah to make a decisive decision on this matter. Their meeting took place approximately two and a half months after the Pledge of Aqabah. All the representatives of the Quraysh tribes converged for this meeting to discuss a decisive plan that would ensure the swift elimination of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his call. When they arrived at Dar al-Nadwah at the appointed time, Iblis intercepted them in the guise of a venerable old man and stood at the door. They asked, "Who is this old man?" He replied, "An old man from Najd who heard about what you have agreed upon and has come to join you to hear what you say, and perhaps he may offer you his opinion and advice." They said, "Yes, enter." So he entered with them. After the meeting was complete and a lengthy discussion ensued, Abu al-Aswad said, "Let us expel him from among us and banish him from our lands, and we will not care where he goes or where he ends up. We will have rectified our affairs and restored our unity as it was." The Najdi old man said, "No, by God, this is not a good opinion for you. Have you not seen the eloquence of his speech, the sweetness of his tongue, and how he has captivated the hearts of men with what he brings? By God, if you do this, you will not be safe from him settling among some Arab tribe, and then marching with them against you, after they have followed him, until he tramples you in your lands and then does to you whatever he wishes. Devise a different plan for him." Abu al-Bakhtari said, "Let us imprison him in chains and lock him behind a door, and then wait for him to meet the fate of those like him among the poets who came before him – Zuhayr and al-Nabighah – and those who have passed from this death, until he meets the same end." The Najdi old man said, "No, by God, this is not a good opinion for you. By God, if you imprison him, as you say, his cause will emerge from behind the door you have locked him behind to his companions, and they will soon rise up against you, snatch him from your hands, and then increase their numbers against you until they overcome you in your affairs. This is not a good opinion for you, so consider something else." After this, the chief of Mecca's criminals, Abu Jahl ibn Hisham, came forward with a sinful proposal that was agreed upon by all present. Abu Jahl said, "By God, I have an opinion on this that I do not think you have yet considered." They asked, "And what is it, O Abu al-Hakam?" He replied, "I suggest that we take a strong, noble, and respected young man from each tribe. Then we give each of these young men a sharp sword, and they all go to him and strike him with a single blow, killing him. Thus, we will be rid of him. For if they do this, his blood will be dispersed among all the tribes, and the Banu Abd Manaf will not be able to fight all their people. They will then accept blood money from us, and we will pay it to them." The Najdi old man said, "The statement is as the man said. This is the opinion, and there is no other opinion." They unanimously agreed to this sinful proposal.

42.title: The migration of the Messenger, peace be upon him, and Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, to Medina.
42.details: Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to the Muslims: "I have been shown the land of your emigration, a land of date palms between two lava fields." These are the two Harrahs. So, those who had emigrated to Medina did so, and most of those who had emigrated to the land of Abyssinia returned to Medina. Abu Bakr prepared to go to Medina, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him: "Take it easy, for I hope I will be given permission." Abu Bakr said: "May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, do you hope for that?" He said: "Yes." So Abu Bakr detained himself to accompany the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he fed two riding beasts he owned with the leaves of the samur tree – which is called khabat – for four months. Ibn Shihab said: Urwah said: Aisha said: One day, while we were sitting in Abu Bakr's house at the height of noon, someone said to Abu Bakr: "Here is the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, veiled, at an hour he does not usually visit us." Abu Bakr said: "May my father and mother be sacrificed for him, by Allah, he has not come at this hour except for something important." She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came and asked for permission, and he was granted permission and entered. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Abu Bakr: "Send out those who are with you." Abu Bakr said: "They are only your family, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "I have been given permission to leave." Abu Bakr said: "To accompany you, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah?" The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Yes." Abu Bakr said: "Then take, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah, one of these two riding beasts of mine." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "For a price." Aisha said: We prepared them with the best possible preparation, and we made provisions for them in a waterskin. Asma bint Abi Bakr cut a piece from her belt and tied it around the mouth of the waterskin. It was because of this that she was named "Dhat al-Nitaqayn" (She of the Two Belts). She said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr joined them in a cave on Mount Thawr, and they hid there for three nights. Abdullah ibn Abi Bakr, a young, intelligent, and quick-witted boy, would spend the night with them, and then leave them before dawn to be with Quraysh in Mecca as if he had spent the night there. He would hear nothing of any plan devised against them without memorizing it, until he would bring them news of it when darkness fell. Amir ibn Fuhayrah, the freed slave of Abu Bakr, would bring them a herd of sheep for grazing, and bring them to rest with them when an hour after Isha had passed. They would spend the night on the milk of their herd and their drink until Amir ibn Fuhayrah would call them at dawn. He did this every night of those three nights. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr hired a man from the tribe of Banu al-Dil, who was from Banu Abd ibn Adi, a guide and an expert navigator – and an expert navigator is one skilled in guidance. He had an alliance with the family of Al-As ibn Wa'il al-Sahmi, and he was on the religion of the disbelievers of Quraysh. So they entrusted him with their riding beasts and agreed to meet him at the cave of Thawr after three nights, with their riding beasts, on the morning of the third day. Amir ibn Fuhayrah and the guide set off with them, and they took the coastal route. Surraqah ibn Ju'shum said: Messengers from the disbelievers of Quraysh came to us, offering a reward for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr, whoever killed or captured either of them. While I was sitting in a gathering of my people, Banu Mudlij, a man from them came and stood before us while we were sitting, and said: "O Surraqah, I have just seen some dark shapes on the coast. I think it is Muhammad and his companions." Surraqah said: I knew it was them, so I said to him: "They are not them, but you saw so-and-so and so-and-so. They have gone from our sight." I then remained in the gathering for a while, then I got up and went inside and ordered my slave girl to bring out my horse from behind a hill and keep it for me. I took my spear and went out with it from the back of the house, and I struck its tip against the ground, and lowered its upper part, until I reached my horse and mounted it. I urged it on, and it brought me closer, until I was near them. My horse stumbled, and I fell off it. I got up and reached for my quiver, and took out the arrows for divination, and cast lots to see if I would harm them or not. The result I disliked came out. I mounted my horse and disobeyed the arrows, and it brought me closer, until when I heard the recitation of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he did not look back, and Abu Bakr kept looking back, my horse's legs sank into the ground, up to its knees. I fell off it, then I urged it on and it rose, and it could hardly pull its legs out. When it stood upright, there was a cloud of dust rising into the sky like smoke from the tracks of its legs. I cast lots again, and the result I disliked came out. I called out to them offering safety, and they stopped. I mounted my horse and rode until I reached them. When I encountered what I encountered of being held back from them, it occurred to me that the cause of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would prevail. I said to him: "Your people have offered a reward for you, and I informed them of what people intended for them. I offered them provisions and supplies, but they did not take anything from me nor ask me, except that he said: 'Conceal yourselves from us.'" I asked him to write me a letter of security, so he ordered Amir ibn Fuhayrah to write it on a piece of leather. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, departed. Urwah ibn al-Zubayr narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, met al-Zubayr with a group of Muslims who were traders returning from Syria. Al-Zubayr clothed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr in white garments. The Muslims in Medina heard of the Messenger of Allah's departure from Mecca, so they would go out every morning to the Harrah and wait for him until the heat of noon drove them back. One day, after waiting for a long time, they returned. When they returned to their homes, a man from the Jews climbed one of their fortresses to look at something. He saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions, dressed in white, shimmering in the heat haze. The Jew could not help but say in a loud voice: "O Arabs, this is your ancestor whom you await!" The Muslims rushed to their weapons and met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, at the back of the Harrah. He turned them to the right, until he settled them in the territory of Banu Amr ibn Awf. This was on Monday in the month of Rabi al-Awwal. Abu Bakr stood up for the people, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sat in silence. Those who came from the Ansar – who had not seen the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him – began to greet Abu Bakr, until the sun shone on the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Abu Bakr came and shaded him with his cloak, and then the people recognized the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

43.title: The construction of the Quba Mosque.
43.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, stayed in the Banu Amr ibn Awf in Quba for over ten nights, and there he founded the mosque which was founded on piety, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed in it.

44.title: The construction of the Prophet's Mosque.
44.details:
The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, mounted his riding beast from Quba and set out, people walking with him until it knelt near the Mosque of the Messenger, peace be upon him, in Medina. On that day, men from among the Muslims were praying there. It was a date palm drying ground belonging to Suhail and Sahl, two orphaned boys under the care of As'ad ibn Zurarah. When his riding beast knelt, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said, "This, God willing, is the place of dwelling." Then the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, called the two boys and negotiated with them for the drying ground to make it a mosque. They said, "No, rather we gift it to you, O Messenger of God." But the Messenger of God refused to accept it as a gift until he bought it from them. Then he built a mosque. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, began to carry bricks with them in its construction, and while carrying bricks, he would say, "This is a burden, not the burden of Khaybar. This is more righteous and purer for our Lord." And he would say, "O God, the reward is the reward of the Hereafter, so have mercy on the Ansar and the Muhajirun."

Anas, may God be pleased with him, said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina and stayed in the upper part of the city in a tribe called Banu 'Amr ibn 'Awf. The Prophet, peace be upon him, stayed with them for fourteen nights. Then he sent for Banu an-Najjar, and they came, girded with swords, as if I were looking at the Prophet, peace be upon him, on his riding beast, with Abu Bakr behind him, and the notables of Banu an-Najjar around him, until he arrived at the courtyard of Abu Ayyub. He used to like to pray wherever prayer found him, and to pray in sheep pens. He ordered the construction of the mosque, so he sent for a group of Banu an-Najjar and said, "O Banu an-Najjar, name your price for this courtyard of yours." They said, "By God, we will not ask for its price except from God." Anas said: It contained, as I tell you, the graves of the polytheists, ruins, and palm trees. The Prophet, peace be upon him, ordered the graves of the polytheists to be exhumed, then the ruins to be leveled, and the palm trees to be cut down. They lined up the palm trees as the qiblah of the mosque, made its doorposts of stone, and began to carry rocks, chanting, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, was with them, saying, "O God, there is no good except the good of the Hereafter, so forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirun." Abdullah ibn Umar said: The mosque in the time of the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, was built with bricks, its roof was made of palm fronds, and its columns were made of palm wood.

45.title: The brotherhood between the Emigrants and the Helpers.
45.details:
Among the consequences of his migration, and that of his Companions, to Medina was the brotherhood established between the Emigrants and the Helpers, may Allah be pleased with them. In the beginning, some of them would inherit from others. It is narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, regarding the verse: {And for each, We have appointed heirs} he said: "Heirs." And regarding: {And those with whom your right hands have covenanted} he said: "When the Emigrants arrived in Medina, an Emigrant would inherit from an Helper, to the exclusion of his own relatives, due to the brotherhood that the Prophet, peace be upon him, had established between them. When the verse {And for each, We have appointed heirs} was revealed, it abrogated that. Then he said: {And those with whom your right hands have covenanted} meaning: "Except for support, assistance, and sincere advice. Inheritance was then abolished, but one would still make a will for them."

Anas narrated: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina, the Emigrants came to him and said: "O Messenger of Allah, we have not seen a people more generous than those among whom we have landed, nor more compassionate with little than they are with much. They have spared us hardship and shared their ease with us, to the extent that we fear they will take all the reward." The Prophet, peace be upon him, replied: "Not so, as long as you supplicate to Allah for them and praise them."

Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, said: When we arrived in Medina, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, established brotherhood between me and Sa'd ibn al-Rabi'. Sa'd ibn al-Rabi' said: "I am the wealthiest of the Helpers. I will give you half of my wealth, and look at whichever of my two wives you desire; I will divorce her for you, and when her waiting period is over, you may marry her." Abd al-Rahman said: "I have no need for that. Is there a market where trade occurs?" He said: "The market of Qaynuqa'." Abd al-Rahman went there and brought back some dried yogurt and ghee. He continued to go daily, and before long, Abd al-Rahman returned with a trace of yellow on him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, asked: "Have you married?" He said: "Yes." He asked: "And whom?" He said: "A woman from the Helpers." He asked: "What did you pay as dowry?" He said: "The weight of a date pit of gold – or a date pit of gold." The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: "Hold a wedding feast, even if it be with a sheep."

46.title: The expedition of Ubaydah ibn al-Harith ibn al-Muttalib to the valley of Rabigh.
46.details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent Ubaydah ibn al-Harith ibn Abd al-Muttalib on a mission to Batn Rabigh – which is the miqat for the people of Sham, Egypt, Turkey, and those who follow their route – in Sha'ban, eight months after the Hijra. He gave him a white banner, which was carried by Misṭaḥ ibn Uthathah ibn al-Muttalib ibn Abd Manaf. They were sixty emigrants, with no Ansar among them. They encountered Abu Sufyan ibn Harb, who was with two hundred men at Batn Rabigh, ten miles from al-Juhfah. There was archery between them, but they did not draw their swords, nor did they line up for battle. It was merely a skirmish. Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas was among them, and he was the first to shoot an arrow in the cause of Allah. Then, both parties returned to their respective encampments.

47.title: The expedition of Hamza to the Sea of Reeds.
47.details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent a detachment to the coast of the sea, appointing Hamza ibn Abd al-Muttalib as its commander. He sent him with thirty riders from the Emigrants. Hamza's banner was the first banner that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, tied, and it was white. Its bearer was Abu Murthad Kannaz ibn Husayn al-Ghanawi, may Allah be pleased with him. The objective of this detachment was to intercept a caravan of Quraysh coming from Sham, which included Abu Jahl ibn Hisham with three hundred men. They reached the coast of the sea near Al-`Is - a place near Medina on the coast of the sea - and they met and lined up for battle. Majdi ibn Amr al-Juhani - who was an ally to both sides - walked between them until he separated them, so they did not fight. Hamza's detachment, may Allah be pleased with him, was at the same time as Ubaydah ibn al-Harith's detachment, may Allah be pleased with him, to Rabigh.

48.title: The expedition of Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Kharrar.
48.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, with twenty of the Emigrants, nine months after the Hijra. It is also said that it was eight. They were sent to Al-Kharrar. He tied a white banner for him, which was carried by Al-Miqdad ibn Amr, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Kharrar is a valley from which one reaches Al-Juhfah. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, instructed him not to go beyond it, so that they might intercept a caravan of Quraysh passing by. They set out on foot, hiding during the day and traveling at night, until they reached the mentioned location at dawn on the fifth day. They found that the caravan had already passed the day before. So they turned back to Medina without engaging in any battle.

49.title: The Battle of al-Abwa' (Waddan) and the truce with Banu Damrah.
49.details: The first expedition the Prophet, peace be upon him, undertook was to Al-Abwa, then to Buwat, then to Al-Ushairah. Al-Ushairah is a village in the region of Al-Fur', located twenty-three miles from Al-Juhfah in the direction of Medina. It is said to have been named thus due to the plague that was there. This was the expedition of Waddan, with a stressed "dal". Ishaq said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out on an expedition himself until he reached Waddan, which is Al-Abwa. He departed from Medina twelve months after his arrival in Medina, intending to confront Quraysh. He made a treaty with Banu Damrah bin Bakr bin Abd Manat, from Kinanah. Their chief, Makhshi bin Amr al-Damri, made a treaty with him, and he returned without fighting. The Prophet, peace be upon him, had appointed Sa'd bin Ubadah as his deputy in Medina. It is also said that when the Prophet, peace be upon him, reached Al-Abwa, he sent Ubaidah bin Al-Harith with sixty men. They encountered a group from Quraysh, and they exchanged arrows. Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas shot an arrow, and he was the first to shoot an arrow in the cause of Allah.

50.title: The First Battle of Badr (Wadi Safwan).
50.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, embarked on the first expedition to Badr until he reached the valley of Safwan. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, set out thirteen months after his Hijra, seeking Kurz ibn Jabir al-Fihri. Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, carried his banner, which was white. He appointed Zayd ibn Harithah as his deputy in Medina. Kurz had raided the herds of Medina – the camels and livestock that grazed in the morning – and had driven them away. He was grazing them in the protected pasture. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, pursued him until he reached a valley called Safwan, in the vicinity of Badr. However, Kurz escaped him and he did not catch him, so he returned to Medina.

51.title: The Battle of Bu'at, near Yanbu.
51.details: Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: We were on an expedition with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to the valley of Buwat, and he was seeking Majdi bin Amr al-Juhani. We were taking turns riding the camel, five, six, or seven of us. It was the turn of an Ansari man to ride his camel. He dismounted it and rode it, then urged it on, but it was slow to respond. He said to it: "Get up, may Allah curse you." The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Who is it that has cursed his camel?" He replied: "I did, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Get off it, and do not accompany us while you are cursed. Do not invoke curses upon yourselves, nor upon your children, nor upon your property, lest you happen to ask Allah for something at a time when He grants requests, and He answers you." Buwat is a mountain in the mountains of Juhaynah, near Yanbu.

52.title: The Battle of Al-Ushairah (Al-Usayrah).
52.details: It was said to Zayd ibn Arqam: "How many expeditions did the Prophet, peace be upon him, participate in?" He said: "Nineteen." It was said: "How many did you participate in with him?" He said: "Seventeen." It was said: "Which one was the first?" He said: "Al-Usayrah, or Al-Ushayr." The expedition of Al-Ushayr occurred before the Battle of Badr. The Prophet, peace be upon him, took the path of Bani Dinar, then the plain of Al-Khabar, and camped under a tree in Batḥā' Ibn Azhar called Dhat Al-Saq. He prayed there... Food was prepared for him there, and he ate from it, and the people ate with him... Water was brought for him from a well called Al-Mushtarib. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, departed, leaving the people to his left, and took a path called Shu'bat Abdullah... Then he descended to the left until he reached Yallil, where he camped at the confluence of Yallil and the confluence of Al-Dab'ah. He drank from a well in Al-Dab'ah, then took the path of Farsh, the path of Malal, until he reached the road at Suhayrat, at Sukhayrat Al-Yamam. Then the road straightened for him until he reached Al-Ushayr from the valley of Yanbu'. He stayed there during Jumada al-Ula and some nights of Jumada al-Akhirah. There, he made a truce with Bani Mudlij and their allies from Bani Damrah, and then returned to Medina without encountering any hardship.

53.title: The expedition of Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, to Rabigh.
53.details: Ibn Asakir narrated from Al-Zuhri, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent a detachment including Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, to a region of the Hijaz called Rabegh. The polytheists attacked the Muslims, and on that day, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, came to them with his arrows. He was the first to shoot an arrow in the cause of Allah, and this was the first battle in Islam."

54.title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Jahsh al-Asadi to Nakhla.
54.details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, sent his messenger Abdullah ibn Jahsh al-Asadi to Nakhlah in Rajab, seventeen months after the Hijra, with twelve men from the Muhajirun, each pair sharing a camel. They reached the valley of Nakhlah to scout a caravan of Quraysh. In this expedition, Abdullah ibn Jahsh was named the Commander of the Faithful. The Messenger of God had written him a letter and ordered him not to look at it until he had traveled for two days, then to look at it. When he opened the letter, he found: "When you look at this letter of mine, proceed until you descend to Nakhlah, between Mecca and Ta'if, and scout Quraysh there, and learn their news for us." He said, "We hear and obey," and informed his companions of this, stating that he did not compel them. Whoever desired martyrdom should proceed, and whoever disliked death should return. As for me, I am proceeding. So they all proceeded. While on the way, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas and Utbah ibn Ghazwan lost a camel they were sharing, so they fell behind to search for it. Abdullah ibn Jahsh proceeded until he reached Nakhlah. A caravan of Quraysh passed by him carrying raisins, dried meat, and merchandise, which included Amr ibn al-Hadrami, Uthman and Nawfal ibn Abdullah ibn al-Mughirah, and al-Hakam ibn Kaysan, a freed slave of Banu al-Mughirah. The Muslims consulted among themselves and said, "We are on the last day of the sacred month of Rajab. If we fight them, we will violate the sacred month. If we leave them tonight, they will enter the sanctuary." Then they agreed to confront them. One of them threw a spear at Amr ibn al-Hadrami and killed him, and they captured Uthman and al-Hakam, while Nawfal escaped. Then they returned with the caravan and the two captives, having set aside the fifth, which was the first fifth in Islam, and the first killing in Islam, and the first two captives in Islam. The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, disapproved of what they had done, and Quraysh's hostility and denial intensified. They claimed to have found a pretext, saying: Muhammad has made the sacred month permissible. This weighed heavily on the Muslims until God Almighty revealed: {They ask you about the sacred month, about fighting in it. Say, "Fighting in it is great [sin], but barring [people] from the way of God and disbelief in Him and [preventing access to] al-Masjid al-Haram and the expulsion of its people from it are greater [evil] with God. And affliction is greater than killing.} [Al-Baqarah: 217].

55.title: The Change of the Qibla to the Kaaba.
55.details: From Al-Bara' ibn 'Azib, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina, he prayed towards Jerusalem for sixteen or seventeen months. He loved to be directed towards the Kaaba, so Allah the Almighty revealed: {We have certainly seen the turning of your face, [O Muhammad], toward the heaven, and We will surely turn you to a qiblah with which you shall be well-pleased} [Al-Baqarah: 144]. So he was directed towards the Kaaba. A man prayed the 'Asr prayer with him, then he went out and passed by some of the Ansar. He said: I bear witness that I prayed with the Prophet, peace be upon him, and that he was directed towards the Kaaba. So they turned while they were bowing in the 'Asr prayer."

56.title: The obligation of fasting the month of Ramadan was revealed.
56.details: In this year, the fasting of the month of Ramadan was ordained. It has also been said that the obligation of fasting the month of Ramadan was before the Battle of Badr.

57.title: The obligation of Zakat al-Fitr was ordained.
57.details: Allah, the Exalted, has ordained the Zakat al-Fitr, which is obligatory upon every Muslim, whether free or slave, male or female, young or old, who is able to pay it. The wisdom behind it is to purify the fasting person from any idle talk or obscenity they may have committed during fasting, and to provide assistance to the poor, bringing them joy on the day of Eid.

58.title: The Expedition of 'Umayr ibn 'Adi, may Allah be pleased with him, to kill 'Asma bint Marwan.
58.details: Asma bint Marwan, from Banu Umayyah ibn Zayd, wife of Yazid ibn Zayd ibn Hisn al-Khatmi, used to criticize Islam, harm the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and incite against him. She would throw menstrual cloths in the mosque of Banu Khatmah. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, declared her blood forfeit. Umayr ibn Adi vowed that if the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned to Medina from Badr, he would kill her, and he did so, may Allah be pleased with him. When Umayr returned, he found her sons with a group burying her. They said, "O Umayr, did you kill her?" He replied, "Yes, so plot against me all together, then give me no respite. By Him in whose hand is my soul, if all of you said what she said, I would strike you with this sword of mine until I die or I kill you." On that day, Islam appeared among Banu Khatmah, and whoever among them had embraced Islam used to conceal it. The first among Banu Khatmah to embrace Islam was Umayr ibn Adi, who is also called Al-Qari.

59.title: The Battle of Badr (the Great) and the Victory of the Muslims.
59.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, dispatched a group of Muslims to intercept the Quraysh caravan coming from Syria, which was led by Abu Sufyan. Abu Sufyan later learned of the Muslims' departure and sent a message to Quraysh calling for their aid to rescue their trade. He also changed his route to save the caravan. Then, the Muslims and the polytheists met at Badr, a place between Mecca and Medina, and closer to Medina than Mecca. The number of polytheists was nearly a thousand, while the number of Muslims was over three hundred. The battle began with the famous duel, then the fighting started and was intense. Prominent leaders of Quraysh, such as Abu Jahl and Umayyah ibn Khalaf, and others were killed, with their total dead reaching seventy men and the same number taken captive. Fourteen Muslims were killed, and some say sixteen. Thus, a great victory was achieved by the Muslims. God Almighty aided them and sent angels to fight alongside them. Regarding the captives, Umar suggested killing them, while Abu Bakr suggested ransoming them. The Prophet, peace be upon him, accepted Abu Bakr's opinion, but revelation descended in agreement with Umar's view. As for the spoils of war, the chapter of Al-Anfal was revealed concerning them.

60.title: The passing of Ruqayyah, may Allah be pleased with her.
60.details: She is Ruqayyah, daughter of the Master of Mankind, peace be upon him. She was the wife of Uthman ibn Affan, may Allah be pleased with them both. Ruqayyah was initially married to Utbah ibn Abi Lahab. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, was sent [with his message], Abu Lahab ordered his son to divorce her. Uthman then married her and migrated with her to Abyssinia. When the Messenger of Allah called upon the people to go out to intercept the caravan of Abu Sufyan, he ordered Uthman to remain with Ruqayyah to nurse her and care for her. This was the reason for his absence. The Prophet, peace be upon him, granted him a share [of the spoils] as he did for those who were present at Badr. Then Ruqayyah did not remain long in her illness before she passed away, may Allah be pleased with her.

61.title: The Expedition of Salim ibn Umayr, may Allah be pleased with him, to Abu Afak the Jew.
61.details: The expedition of Salim bin Umayr, may Allah be pleased with him, to Abu Afak the Jew took place in Shawwal, at the beginning of the twentieth month after the Hijra of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Abu Afak was from the Banu Amr bin Awf, an old man who had reached the age of one hundred and twenty years. He was a Jew, greatly disbelieving, and a harsh critic of the Muslims. His heart was filled with hatred and envy towards the Muslims as he saw the Aws and Khazraj rallying to support the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. His malice towards Islam and its people intensified after he saw the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, growing stronger and more established in Medina and its surroundings after the Battle of Badr. He could not bear it, so he began to recite poetry, denouncing the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, inciting enmity towards him, and ridiculing the opinion of the Ansar for following and supporting the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Salim bin Umayr, who was one of the "weepers" – meaning during the Battle of Tabuk – and a participant in the Battle of Badr, said: "I vow to kill Abu Afak or die trying." He waited, seeking an opportunity, until one summer night when Abu Afak slept in the courtyard. Salim bin Umayr heard of this, approached him, placed his sword on his abdomen, and then leaned on it until it sank into his body. The enemy of Allah cried out, and some of his followers came to him, brought him into his house, and buried him. Abu Afak was among those whose hypocrisy became evident when the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, killed Al-Harith bin Suwayd bin Al-Samit. Salim participated in the Battle of Badr, Uhud, the Trench, and all the other battles with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He passed away during the caliphate of Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan, may Allah be pleased with them both.

62.title: The Battle of Banu Qaynuqa.
62.details: Most historians of battles and biographies mentioned that it occurred after Badr, and Ibn Hajar favored this view. It took place on Saturday, the middle of Shawwal. The report of the expulsion of Banu Qaynuqa' is established in the two Sahih collections. It is narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: "An-Nadir and Qurayzah fought, so he expelled Banu An-Nadir and let Qurayzah and those with them remain, until Qurayzah fought. Then he killed their men and divided their women, children, and property among the Muslims, except for some of them who joined the Prophet, peace be upon him, and he granted them safety and they embraced Islam. And he expelled all the Jews of Medina: Banu Qaynuqa' – who were the kin of Abdullah ibn Salam – and the Jews of Banu Harithah, and all the Jews of Medina."

63.title: The Expedition of As-Sawiq, or the Expedition of Banu Sulaym (Qarqarat al-Kadr).
63.details: After the defeat of the polytheists at Badr, Abu Sufyan vowed that no water from ritual impurity would touch his head until he invaded Muhammad, peace be upon him, and his companions and took revenge on the Muslims. So he set out with two hundred riders from Quraysh, to fulfill his oath. He reached the outskirts of Medina at night and sought refuge with Banu Nadir. He went to Huyayy ibn Akhtab and knocked on his door, but Huyayy refused to open it for him, fearing him. So Abu Sufyan turned away from him to Salam ibn Mishkam, who was the chief of Banu Nadir at that time and the keeper of their treasure. Abu Sufyan asked for permission to enter, and he was granted it. Salam hosted him, gave him wine to drink, and informed him of the news of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Then Abu Sufyan left in the latter part of that night and went to his companions. He sent some men from Quraysh, who went to an area of Medina called Al-Arid – a valley in Medina. They set fire to the fruit-bearing trees and date palms of the Muslims. They found a man from the Ansar and his ally in their fields and killed them, then they turned back. When this news reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he set out in pursuit of them with two hundred of the Emigrants and Helpers. He appointed Abu Lubaba Bashir ibn Abd al-Mundhir, may Allah be pleased with him, as governor of Medina. Abu Sufyan and his companions began to throw down sacks of saweeq – roasted wheat or barley, then ground, and used as provisions, mixed with water, ghee, or honey – which was the majority of their provisions, to lighten their load for escape. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, reached Qaraqarah al-Kadr – Qaraqarah: level ground. Al-Kadr: a water source belonging to Banu Sulaym, and the origin of Kadr is a bird with a dusky color, after which the place or water was named. Then he turned back towards Medina, as Abu Sufyan and his companions had escaped him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was away for five days. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned with them, the Muslims said, "O Messenger of Allah, do you hope that this will be a raid for us?" He said, "Yes." This raid is also called the "Raid of Saweeq" because the most of what the people threw away from their provisions was saweeq, so the Muslims returned with a lot of saweeq. This occurred in Shawwal in the second year of the Hijra.

65.title: The Killing of Ka'b ibn al-Ashraf.
65.details: Ka'b ibn al-Ashraf was a man from the tribe of Tayy, and his mother was from the Banu Nadir, a Jewish tribe. He was a poet who used to lampoon the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his companions, inciting hatred against them and causing them harm. When the Battle of Badr occurred, he was disheartened and humiliated, saying, "The belly of the earth is better than its surface today." He then went to Mecca, wept for the slain Quraysh, and incited them with poetry. Jabir ibn Abdullah narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said, "Who will deal with Ka'b ibn al-Ashraf? For he has indeed harmed Allah and His Messenger." Muhammad ibn Maslamah said, "O Messenger of Allah, would you like me to kill him?" He replied, "Yes." He said, "Grant me permission to speak." The Prophet said, "Speak." So, Muhammad ibn Maslamah went to Ka'b and said to him, mentioning what transpired between them, "This man has asked for charity and has burdened us." When Ka'b heard this, he said, "And by Allah, you will soon be weary of him." Muhammad replied, "We have followed him now, and we dislike leaving him until we see what becomes of his affair. He also said, "And I wanted you to lend me some money." Ka'b asked, "What will you give me as collateral?" Muhammad replied, "What do you want?" Ka'b said, "You will give us your women as collateral." Muhammad replied, "You are the most handsome of the Arabs; shall we give you our women as collateral!?" Ka'b then said, "You will give me your children as collateral." Muhammad replied, "One of our children is insulted, and it is said, 'He was ransomed for two measures of dates.' But we will give you our weapons as collateral." Ka'b said, "Then fine." He promised to bring him Al-Harith, Abu 'Abs ibn Jabr, and 'Abbad ibn Bishr. Muhammad said, "So they came and called him at night, and he came down to them." Sufyan said, "Others than 'Amr said: His wife said to him, 'I hear a sound like the sound of blood.' He said, 'It is only Muhammad ibn Maslamah, his companion, and Abu Na'ilah. Indeed, the generous man, if invited to a stab in the night, would respond.' Muhammad said, 'When he comes, I will reach for his head, and when I have a firm grip on him, then it is yours.' He said, 'When he came down, he was wearing perfume. They said, "We detect the scent of perfume on you." He said, "Yes, so-and-so is under me; she is the most fragrant of the Arab women." He said, "Will you permit me to smell it?" He said, "Yes, smell it." So he took it and smelled it, then said, "Will you permit me to return?" He said, "He gained a firm grip on his head, then said, 'It is yours.'" He said, "So they killed him." (...Then they came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and informed him.)

66.title: The raid of Ghatafan on Najd (the Raid of Dhu Amr).
66.details: This was the Ghazwah of Dhu Amarr, in the region of Najd. The reason for it was that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, received news that a group from Banu Tha'labah ibn Sa'id ibn Dhubyan ibn Baghidh ibn Ra'ith ibn Ghatafan, and Banu Muharib ibn Khasafah ibn Qays, at Dhu Amarr, had gathered, intending to raid the frontiers of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. A man from them, called Du'thur ibn Al-Harith ibn Muharib, had united them. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, summoned the Muslims and set out with four hundred and fifty men, accompanied by several horses. He appointed Uthman ibn Affan as his deputy in Medina. They encountered a man from them at Dhu al-Qassah, called Jabbar from Banu Tha'labah. The Muslims asked him, "Where are you going?" He replied, "I am going to Yathrib to scout for myself and look around." He was brought to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and informed him of their news. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said, "They will not meet you. If they hear of your march, they will flee to the mountain tops. I am going with you." So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, invited Jabbar to Islam, and he embraced Islam. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, attached him to Bilal, and Jabbar led them along a path, bringing them down to them. The people heard of the march of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and fled to the mountain tops. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, reached a water source called Dhu Amarr and camped there. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions were struck by heavy rain, and the clothes of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions became wet. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, descended under a tree and spread his clothes to dry, and lay down, while the polytheists could see him. The Muslims were occupied with their affairs. The polytheists sent a brave man from them, called Du'thur ibn Al-Harith, who was their chief and bravest. He was girded with a sword. Du'thur rushed forward, drawing his sword, until he stood over the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, with his sword drawn, and said, "O Muhammad, who will protect you from me today?" The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, replied, "Allah." Gabriel pushed him in the chest, and the sword fell from his hand. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, took it and said to him, "Who will protect you from me?!" He replied, "No one." And I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. By Allah, I will never gather a force against you again. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gave him his sword. Then he came to his people, and they asked him, "What happened to you? Woe to you!" He said, "I saw a tall man who pushed me in the chest, and I fell on my back. I knew he was an angel, and I testified that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. By Allah, I will never gather a force against him again." And he began to call his people to Islam. And Allah, the Almighty, revealed: "O you who have believed, remember the favor of Allah upon you when a people intended to extend their hands [in aggression] against you, but He restrained their hands from you." [Al-Ma'idah, 11]. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, returned to Medina without encountering any harm. His absence was fifteen nights. It was also said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stayed in Najd for the entire month of Safar.

67.title: The Battle of Bu'ran between Al-Fur' and Medina.
67.details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, went on an expedition intending to confront Quraysh, and he appointed Abdullah ibn Umm Maktum, may God be pleased with him, as his deputy in Medina. He proceeded until he reached Buhran, in the vicinity of al-Fur'. The reason for this expedition was that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, learned that a large gathering of Banu Sulaym ibn Mansur was present there. So he set out with three hundred of his companions, and he did not reveal the purpose of his journey. When he was one night's journey from Buhran, he encountered a man from Banu Sulaym, who informed them that the people had dispersed. He detained the man with another companion and proceeded until he arrived at Buhran, finding no one there. He stayed for a few days, then returned without encountering any hostility, and released the man. Then he turned back, returning to Medina.

68.title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah.
68.details: After their defeat in the Battle of Badr, the polytheists of Mecca began searching for another route for their trade to Syria. Some of them suggested the route of Najd in Iraq, and they indeed took it. Merchants set out from them, including Abu Sufyan ibn Harb, Safwan ibn Umayyah, and Huwaytib ibn Abd al-Uzza, carrying silver and many goods valued at one hundred thousand dirhams. This news reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, through Sulait ibn al-Nu'man, may Allah be pleased with him. So, he sent Zaid ibn Harithah with one hundred riders to intercept the caravan. Zaid encountered the caravan at a watering place called al-Qardah, which is one of the watering places of Najd. Its men fled in terror, and the Muslims seized the caravan and its contents. They captured its guide, Furat ibn Hayyan, who embraced Islam at the hands of the Prophet, peace be upon him. They returned to Medina, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, distributed one-fifth of the spoils and divided the remainder among the members of the expedition.

69.title: The Battle of Uhud and the Reason for the Muslims' Defeat.
69.details:
The reason for this was that when the polytheists suffered casualties among their nobles at the Battle of Badr, and the caravan with its trade goods, which was with Abu Sufyan, escaped, upon their return to Mecca, the sons of those who were killed and the leaders of those who remained said to Abu Sufyan: "Amass these funds for the war against Muhammad." So they spent them for that purpose, gathered armies and allied tribes, and marched with nearly three thousand men, until they encamped near Uhud, facing Medina.

On Friday, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed. After finishing, he prayed over a man from Banu Najjar, named Malik ibn Amr. He then consulted the people, asking whether they should march out to meet the enemy or remain in Medina. Abdullah ibn Ubayy suggested staying in Medina. He argued that if they stayed, they would be in a terrible confinement, and if the enemy entered, the men would fight them face-to-face, while the women and children would pelt them with stones from above. If the enemy retreated, they would return in defeat. Other Companions, who had not witnessed Badr, suggested marching out to meet them. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went inside, donned his armor, and marched out to meet them.

He set out with a thousand of his Companions. When they reached a place called Ash-Shawtt, Abdullah ibn Ubayy turned back with a third of the army, angered because his opinion had not been heeded. He and his followers said: "If we knew there would be fighting today, we would have followed you, but we do not see you fighting today." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, continued his march until he reached the valley of Uhud, at the entrance of the valley. He positioned his back and his camp towards Uhud and prepared for battle with seven hundred of his Companions. He appointed Abdullah ibn Jubayr, brother of Banu Amr ibn Awf, as the commander of the archers, who numbered fifty men that day. He instructed them: "Repel the cavalry from us with arrows, so they do not come at us from behind. Whether we gain victory or suffer defeat, remain in your position, so that we are not attacked from your side." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, wore two coats of mail and gave the banner to Mus'ab ibn Umayr, brother of Banu Abd ad-Dar. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, permitted some of the young boys to participate that day and deferred others.

Quraysh mobilized, numbering three thousand men, with two hundred horses prepared for battle. They appointed Khalid ibn al-Walid to command the right flank of the cavalry and Ikrimah ibn Abi Jahl to command the left flank. The banner was given to Banu Abd ad-Dar.

Then, what happened between the two factions occurred. Initial signs of victory began to appear for the Muslims. When the Muslims saw the polytheists retreating, the archers neglected the Prophet's command to them and descended to collect spoils. Khalid ibn al-Walid seized the opportunity, circled behind them, and engaged them in battle, which led to a reversal of fortunes. The battle concluded with the martyrdom of seventy Muslims, including Hamzah ibn Abd al-Muttalib, Mus'ab ibn Umayr, Abdullah ibn Haram, the father of Jabir, and Abdullah ibn Jubayr, the commander of the archers.

70.title: The martyrdom of Hamza, may Allah be pleased with him, in the Battle of Uhud.
70.details: 'Ubayd Allah ibn 'Adi ibn al-Khiyar narrated that he asked Wahshi, the killer of Hamza, "Will you not tell us about the killing of Hamza?" He replied, "Yes. Hamza killed Tu'aymah ibn 'Adi ibn al-Khiyar at Badr. My master, Jubayr ibn Mut'im, said to me, 'If you kill Hamza for my uncle, you are free.' So, when the people went out for the battle of 'Aynayn, and 'Aynayn is a mountain opposite Uhud, with a valley between them, I went out with the people to fight. When they lined up for battle, Sibā' came out and said, 'Is there any duelist?' Hamza ibn 'Abd al-Muttalib came out to him and said, 'O Sibā', O son of Umm Anmar, the cutter of the clitorises, do you defy Allah and His Messenger (peace be upon him)?' Then he attacked him, and he was like yesterday's gone. I lay in wait for Hamza behind a rock. When he came near me, I threw my spear at him, and it lodged in his chest until it came out from between his legs. That was the last I saw of him. When the people returned, I returned with them. I stayed in Mecca until Islam became widespread. Then I went to Ta'if. They sent a messenger to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and I was told, 'He does not harm messengers.' So I went out with them until I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). When he saw me, he said, 'Are you Wahshi?' I said, 'Yes.' He said, 'Did you kill Hamza?' I said, 'What reached you of the matter has happened.' He said, 'Can you hide your face from me?' So I left. When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed away, Musaylimah the Liar emerged. I said, 'I will go out to Musaylimah, perhaps I will kill him and make it equivalent for Hamza.' So I went out with the people, and what happened, happened. I saw a man standing in a breach of a wall, like a tawny camel with disheveled hair. I threw my spear at him, and it lodged between his chest and his navel until it came out from between his shoulders. Then a man from the Ansar rushed at him and struck him on the head with his sword."

71.title: The Battle of Hamra al-Asad.
71.details:
Ibn Kathir said in his Tafsir of the verse: "{Those who responded to Allah and the Messenger, even after they had been wounded}" This was on the day of Hamra' al-Asad. When the polytheists inflicted what they inflicted upon the Muslims – meaning on the day of Uhud – they turned back towards their lands. As they continued on their journey, they regretted not having finished off the people of Medina and made it the decisive blow. When this reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he called upon the Muslims to go after them to instill fear in them and show them that they possessed strength and resilience. He did not permit anyone except those who had been present at the battle of Uhud, except for Jabir ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him. The Muslims responded, despite their wounds and exhaustion, in obedience to Allah the Almighty and His Messenger, peace be upon him.

It was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that she said regarding the verse: "{Those who responded to Allah and the Messenger, even after they had been wounded – for those among them who did good and feared Allah will have a great reward.}" She said to Urwah: "O son of my sister, your fathers were among them: Al-Zubayr and Abu Bakr. When what happened to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, happened on the day of Uhud, and the polytheists departed from him, he feared they might return. He said: 'Who will go after them?' So seventy men volunteered from them. She said: 'Abu Bakr and Al-Zubayr were among them.'"

Ibn Kathir said after mentioning this Hadith: "(This narration is very strange, for it is well-known among the scholars of Maghazi that those who went out with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to Hamra' al-Asad were all who had witnessed Uhud, and they were seven hundred. Seventy of them were killed, and the rest remained)."

The apparent meaning is that there is no contradiction between the words of Aisha and the scholars of Maghazi, because the meaning of her statement: "So seventy men volunteered for it" is that they preceded others, and then the rest joined them. Hamra' al-Asad is located eight miles from Medina.

72.title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Abi Sarh, may Allah be pleased with him, to Qatan.
72.details: The expedition of Abu Salamah Abdullah bin Abdul-Asad, who was the cousin of the Prophet, peace be upon him, through his paternal aunt Barrah bint Abdul-Muttalib, and his foster brother, as they were both nursed by Thuwibah. Qatan is a mountain, and it is also said to be a water source belonging to Banu Asad. The reason for this expedition was that a man from Tayy, named Al-Walid bin Zuhayr bin Tarif, came to Medina to visit his niece, Zaynab, who was married to Tulayb bin Umayr bin Wahb. He was informed that Tulayhah and Salamah, the sons of Khuwaylid, had gathered their people and those who obeyed them to wage war against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Qays bin Al-Harith advised them against it, but they disobeyed. When this reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he summoned Abu Salamah, may Allah be pleased with him, and said, "Go forth on this expedition, for I have appointed you in command of it." He tied a banner for him and said, "Travel until you reach the land of Banu Asad bin Khuzaymah, and raid them before their forces can gather against you." He also advised him to fear Allah, the Almighty, and to treat the Muslims with him well. So, one hundred and fifty men went with him on this expedition, and the man from Tayy accompanied them as a guide. He traveled swiftly, diverting them from the main road, and journeyed day and night. They outpaced any news and arrived at Dhi Qatan, a water source of Banu Asad, where their forces were gathered. They raided their livestock and captured three shepherds, while the rest escaped. They went to their people and informed them of the news, warning them about Abu Salamah's forces and exaggerating their numbers. Consequently, the gathered forces dispersed in all directions. Abu Salamah arrived at the water source to find the gathering had dispersed. He made camp and divided his companions into three groups to pursue the camels and sheep. One group remained with him, while the other two raided in different directions. He instructed them not to go too far in their pursuit and to return to him if they were safe, and not to separate. He appointed a leader from among them for each group. They all returned to him safely, having acquired camels and sheep, and without encountering anyone. Abu Salamah then headed back to Medina with all the spoils, accompanied by the man from Tayy. After they had traveled for a night, Abu Salamah divided the spoils, setting aside the special share for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, which was a slave. He also set aside the fifth (khums) and gave the guide from Tayy his satisfaction from the spoils. Then he divided the remainder among his companions, and each person received seven camels. He arrived in Medina with all of this without facing any opposition.

73.title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Unays al-Juhani to Sufyan ibn Khalid in Batn Urnah.
73.details: Abdullah bin Unais, may Allah be pleased with him, departed from Medina on Monday, five nights into Muharram, thirty-five months after the Hijra of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. It reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, that Sufyan bin Khalid bin Nabih al-Hudhali, then al-Lahyani – who resided in Urnah and its vicinity with some of his people and others – intended to gather forces against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and that many people from various backgrounds had joined him. Abdullah bin Unais, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, summoned me and said: "It has reached me that Sufyan bin Khalid bin Nabih is gathering people against me to attack me, and he is in Nakhla or Urnah. Go to him and kill him." I said: O Messenger of Allah, describe him to me so I can recognize him. He said: "The sign between you and him is that when you see him, you will be awestruck and fearful of him, and you will feel a shiver, and you will remember Satan." Abdullah said: I was not afraid of men, so I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have never been afraid of anything. He said: "Yes; that is the sign between you and him: you will feel a shiver when you see him." He said: I asked permission from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to speak. He said: "Say what you wish." And he said: "Claim kinship with Khuzā'ah." So I took my sword and added nothing to it, and I went out claiming kinship with Khuzā'ah. When I reached the valley of Urnah, I met him walking, with a group of Abyssinians behind him. When I saw him, I was awestruck by him and recognized him by the description the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had given me. I said: Allah and His Messenger have spoken the truth. The time for Asr prayer had arrived when I saw him, so I prayed while walking, gesturing with my head. When I approached him, he said: "Who is the man?" I said: "A man from Khuzā'ah. I heard about your gathering against Muhammad, so I came to be with you in it." He said: "Yes; I am indeed among those gathered against him." So I walked with him and talked to him. He found my conversation pleasant, and I recited poetry to him, saying: "How strange is what Muhammad has introduced of this new religion! He has abandoned the ways of our fathers and deemed their wisdom foolish." He said: "I have not met anyone like me, nor anyone who fights as well as I do." He was leaning on a staff, striking the ground with it, until he reached his tent, and his companions dispersed to nearby dwellings, while they surrounded him. He said: "Come here, O brother of Khuzā'ah." I approached him. He said: "Sit down." I sat with him until the people calmed down and slept. I took advantage of the opportunity. In most narrations, it is said that I walked with him until, when I had the opportunity, I struck him with my sword and killed him, and took his head. Then I turned and ascended a mountain, and entered a cave. The pursuit of horses and men came from all directions, while I was hidden in the cave. A man approached with his water skin and sandals in his hand. I was afraid. He put down his water skin and sandals and sat down to urinate near the mouth of the cave. Then he said to his companions: "There is no one in the cave." So they turned back. I went out to the water skin, drank what was in it, and took the two sandals and put them on. I traveled by night and hid by day until I came to Medina. I found the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in the mosque. When he saw me, he said: "May your face be successful." I said: "And may your face be successful, O Messenger of Allah." I placed the head before him and told him my story. He gave me a staff and said: "Use this to lean on in Paradise; for those who lean on staffs in Paradise are few." The staff remained with Abdullah bin Unais until his death approached. He instructed his family to wrap the staff in his shroud. They did so. Ibn 'Uqbah said: "They claim that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, informed them of Abdullah bin Unais killing Sufyan bin Khalid before Abdullah bin Unais, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him, arrived."

74.title: The Expedition of the Day of Ar-Raj'i.
74.details:
Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent out a detachment of ten men as scouts, and appointed Asim bin Thabit Al-Ansari, the grandfather of Asim bin Umar bin Al-Khattab, as their commander. They set out until they reached Al-Hada, which is between Usfan and Mecca. They were discovered by a tribe of Hudhayl called Banu Lihyan. Nearly two hundred archers from their tribe mobilized and tracked their footsteps until they found traces of their meal, dates they had provisioned from Medina. They said, "These are dates from Yathrib." They continued to track their footsteps. When Asim and his companions saw them, they took refuge in a mound of sand, and the enemy surrounded them. They called out to them, "Come down and surrender yourselves, and you will have our covenant and pledge, and we will not kill any of you." Asim bin Thabit, the commander of the detachment, said, "As for me, by Allah, I will not descend under the protection of a disbeliever today. O Allah, inform Your Prophet about us." So they shot arrows at them, and killed Asim and seven of his companions. Three men then descended to them under the covenant and pledge: Khubayb Al-Ansari, Ibn Dathinah, and another man. When they had control over them, they loosened the strings of their bows and bound them. The third man said, "This is the first act of treachery. By Allah, I will not accompany you. I have an example in these slain men," referring to the killed companions. They dragged him and tried to persuade him to accompany them, but he refused, so they killed him. They then took Khubayb and Ibn Dathinah and sold them in Mecca after the Battle of Badr. Khubayb was bought by the sons of Al-Harith bin Amir bin Nawfal bin Abd Manaf. Khubayb had killed Al-Harith bin Amir on the day of Badr. Khubayb remained a captive with them. Ubayd Allah bin Iyad informed me that the daughter of Al-Harith told him that when they gathered, she lent Khubayb a razor to shave with. She said that she found him sitting on his thigh with the razor in his hand, holding her son. She was frightened, a fear that Khubayb recognized in her face. He said, "Are you afraid that I will kill him? I would never do that. By Allah, I have never seen a better captive than Khubayb. By Allah, I once found him eating a bunch of grapes in his hand, while he was bound in chains, and there were no fruits in Mecca at that time." She used to say, "This is sustenance from Allah that He provided for Khubayb." When they went out of the sanctuary to kill him in the open, Khubayb said to them, "Let me pray two rak'ahs." They let him. He prayed two rak'ahs, then said, "Were it not that you would think I was afraid, I would have prolonged it. O Allah, count them and destroy them. Then he recited:
"I do not care when I am killed as a Muslim,
On whichever side it may be for Allah's decree.
And if He wills, He will bless the scattered limbs.
Al-Harith's son killed him. Khubayb was the one who initiated the two rak'ahs for every Muslim who is killed patiently. Allah answered the prayer of Asim bin Thabit when he was struck. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed his companions of their news and what had befallen them. Some of the disbelievers of Quraysh sent to Asim, when they heard he was killed, to bring something from him as identification. He had killed one of their great men on the day of Badr. Then, a swarm of wasps, like a canopy, was sent upon Asim, and it protected him from their messengers, so they were unable to cut any of his flesh.

75.title: The Expedition of Bi'r Ma'unah.
75.details: Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that Ri'l, Dhakwan, 'Usayyah, and Bani Lihyan sought the help of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, against an enemy. So he sent them seventy of the Ansar, whom we used to call the Qurra' (reciters) in their time. They used to gather firewood during the day and pray at night. Until they reached Bi'r Ma'unah, where they were killed and betrayed. When this news reached the Prophet, peace be upon him, he performed the Qunut for a month, supplicating in the morning prayer against certain tribes of the Arabs, namely Ri'l, Dhakwan, 'Usayyah, and Bani Lihyan. Anas said: "We used to recite a portion of the Quran about them, then that was abrogated: 'Convey from us to our people that we have met our Lord, and He is pleased with us and has pleased us.' And in a narration with Bukhari, it is mentioned that those seventy Ansar were killed at Bi'r Ma'unah. Anas bin Malik also narrated: Some people came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: 'Send us men to teach us the Quran and the Sunnah.' So he sent them seventy men from the Ansar, who were called the Qurra'. Among them was my uncle Haram. They used to recite the Quran and study at night to learn. During the day, they would bring water and place it in the mosque, and they would gather firewood, sell it, and buy food with it for the people of the Suffah and the poor. The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent them to those people. They were ambushed and killed before they reached their destination. They said: 'O Allah, convey to our Prophet that we have met You, and we are pleased with You, and You are pleased with us.' It was narrated that a man came up behind Haram, the uncle of Anas, and stabbed him with a spear until it pierced him. Haram said: 'By the Lord of the Ka'bah, I have succeeded!' The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to his companions: 'Your brothers have been killed, and they said: O Allah, convey to our Prophet that we have met You, and we are pleased with You, and You are pleased with us.'"

76.title: The Expedition of Banu Nadir.
76.details: The reason for this was that when the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, were killed at the Well of Ma'unah, and they were seventy in number, and 'Amr ibn Umayyah al-Dhamri escaped from them. When he was on his way back to Medina, he killed two men from Banu 'Amir, who had a treaty and a pledge of safety from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, which 'Amr did not know about. When he returned, he informed the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him... So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out to Banu an-Nadir seeking their help in the blood money for those two men. The dwellings of Banu an-Nadir were outside Medina, a few miles to its east. Muhammad ibn Ishaq ibn Yasar said in his book "Al-Sirah": Then the Messenger of Allah went out to Banu an-Nadir, seeking their help in the blood money for those two killed men from Banu 'Amir, whom 'Amr ibn Umayyah al-Dhamri had killed, due to the protection that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had granted them... When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came to them seeking their help in the blood money for those two killed men, they said: Yes, O Abu al-Qasim, we will help you in whatever you wish and have sought our help for. Then they conferred among themselves and said: You will not find the man in such a situation as this – and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was beside a wall of their houses – so who will go up onto this house and throw a rock at him, and rid us of him? 'Amr ibn Jahsh ibn Ka'b, one of them, volunteered and said: I will do it. So he climbed up to throw a rock at him as they had said, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was with a group of his companions, including Abu Bakr, 'Umar, and 'Ali, may Allah be pleased with them. Then the news came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from heaven about what the people intended, so he stood up and left, returning to Medina. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, was delayed, his companions went looking for him and met a man coming from Medina. They asked him about him, and he said: I saw him entering Medina. So the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came back until they reached him, and he informed them of the news of what the Jews had intended to do to him treacherously. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered them to prepare for war against them and to march towards them. Then he marched until he reached them, and they fortified themselves in their fortresses. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered the cutting down and burning of their palm trees. They called out to him: O Muhammad, you used to forbid corruption and criticize those who did it, so what about cutting down and burning the palm trees?! A group from Banu 'Awf ibn al-Khazraj, including 'Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul, Wardi'ah, Malik ibn Abi Qawqal, Suwayd, and Da'is, had sent to Banu an-Nadir saying: Stand firm and resist, for we will not hand you over. If you are fought, we will fight with you, and if you are expelled, we will go out with you. They waited for this support from them, but it did not come, and Allah cast terror into their hearts. So they asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to expel them and spare their blood, on the condition that they would have whatever their camels could carry of their property, except for the rings. So he agreed. They carried away from their property what the camels could bear, and a man among them would dismantle his house from the frame of his door, place it on the back of his camel, and take it away. So they went out to Khaybar, and some of them went to Syria, leaving the property to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and it was exclusively for the Messenger of Allah. It is confirmed in Sahih al-Bukhari that the Prophet, peace be upon him, expelled Banu an-Nadir. And the Surah Al-Hashr was revealed concerning them.

77.title: The Battle of Dhat al-Riqa'.
77.details: Jabir ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to Dhat al-Riqa' from Nakhla. He encountered a gathering of Ghatafan, but there was no fighting. The people frightened each other. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed the prayer of fear. And Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, said: We went out with the Prophet, peace be upon him, on an expedition, and we were six men. We took turns riding a camel. Our feet became blistered, and my feet became blistered, and my fingernails fell off. We used to wrap rags around our feet. So it was named the expedition of Dhat al-Riqa' because of the rags we tied around our feet. Abu Musa narrated this, then he disliked it and said: I wish I had not mentioned it, as if he disliked that anything of his deeds was revealed. And from Salih ibn Khawwat, from one who witnessed the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, praying the prayer of fear on the day of Dhat al-Riqa': A group stood in prayer with him, and another group faced the enemy. He prayed one rak'ah with those who were with him, then he remained standing, and they completed the prayer on their own. Then they departed and stood facing the enemy. The other group came, and he prayed with them the remaining rak'ah of his prayer, then he remained seated, and they completed the prayer on their own, and he gave the salutation with them. This was the expedition against Muharib, Khasafa, and Banu Tha'labah of Ghatafan. And from Jabir ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both: The Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed the prayer of fear with his companions in the seventh expedition, the expedition of Dhat al-Riqa'. And from Jabir, he said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed with them on the day of Muharib and Tha'labah.

78.title: The Battle of Badr al-Maw'id (Second Badr).
78.details: This expedition is called the Lesser Badr, the Small Badr, the Second Badr, and Badr of the Promise. This is due to the appointment made with Abu Sufyan ibn Harb on the day of Uhud. When Abu Sufyan departed from Uhud, he called out, "Your appointment is Badr, next year." When the fourth year of the Hijra arrived, the Messenger, peace be upon him, set out with fifteen hundred of his companions to Badr, accompanied by ten horses. His banner was carried by Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. This was in anticipation of the arrival of the Quraysh according to the appointed time set since the Battle of Uhud with Abu Sufyan, the leader of the Quraysh. The Muslims waited for eight days without the Quraysh arriving. Abu Sufyan had set out with two thousand men and fifty horses. When they reached Marr al-Dhuhran, forty miles from Mecca, they turned back, claiming that the year was one of drought. Their breaking of the promise had the effect of strengthening the position of the Muslims and restoring their prestige. The Muslims continued to send their detachments to various parts of Najd and Hijaz to discipline the Bedouins. Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah led a detachment to Tayy and Asad in Najd, and they dispersed into the mountains without any fighting occurring. The Messenger, peace be upon him, led an army of one thousand fighters in the month of Rabi al-Awwal in the fifth year towards Dumat al-Jandal, having been informed of a gathering of polytheists there. However, the gathering dispersed upon learning of the Muslims' arrival. The Muslims stayed in the area for several days, during which they sent out detachments. They encountered no resistance and returned to Medina after making a truce upon their return with Uyaynah ibn Hisn al-Fazari.

79.title: The Incident of the Lie
79.details: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to the Banu Mustaliq to wage war against them, he drew lots among his wives to decide who would accompany him. The lot fell upon Aisha, the pure, may Allah be pleased with her. On the journey back, she was carried in a howdah. Allah decreed that on that day, she would be outside her howdah searching for a necklace that had fallen from her. When they intended to depart, they did not realize her absence and left. She was young and light in weight. When she returned, she did not see them. Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: "I made my way to the place where I had been, thinking that the people would miss me and return for me. While I was sitting in my place, sleep overcame me, and I slept. Safwan ibn al-Mu'attal al-Sulami, then al-Dhukwani, had camped behind the army and traveled at night. He came upon my resting place in the morning and saw the silhouette of a sleeping person. He came to me and recognized me when he saw me, as he had seen me before the veil was imposed upon me. I awoke to his exclamation of recognition. I covered my face with my garment, and by Allah, he did not speak a word to me, nor did I hear a word from him except his exclamation. Then he made his mount kneel, and it stepped on her hand, so I mounted it. He set off, leading the mount with me on it, until we reached the army, after they had dismounted in the heat of noon. So, those who were destroyed were destroyed concerning my affair. The one who bore the greatest part of it was Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul..." They accused her along with Safwan, and this clear slander began to spread in Medina. Aisha remained for a month, knowing nothing of it, until she learned of it directly from Umm Mistah. All this time, the truth had not been clarified. Then verses were revealed, to be recited until the Day of Resurrection, from His saying, the Almighty: {Indeed, those who came with the slander were a group among you. Do not think it evil for you; rather, it is good for you.} [An-Nur: 11] to His saying: {But Allah purifies whom He wills, and Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing.} [An-Nur: 21] Verses that exonerate the pure, the purified, from what the slanderers fabricated.

80.title: The Expedition of Dumat al-Jandal.
80.details: The raid on Dumat al-Jandal – a place on the edge of Syria, five nights from it and Damascus, and fifteen or sixteen nights from Medina – took place in Rabi' al-Awwal of the fifth year of the Hijra. Its cause was that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, received news that there was a large gathering of tribes in Dumat al-Jandal, and that they wronged those who passed by them, plundered what they had, and intended to approach Medina to attack it. So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, called the people to arms, and appointed Sibaa' ibn 'Arfatah al-Ghifari as his deputy in Medina. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, set out with a thousand Muslims. They traveled by night and hid by day. With him, peace be upon him, was a guide from Banu 'Udhrah named Madhkur. When they approached Dumat al-Jandal, they attacked their livestock and shepherds, and seized what they could. Those who could, fled in all directions. When the people of Dumat al-Jandal learned of this, they dispersed. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, encamped in their vicinity but found no one there. He stayed for a few days and dispatched scouting parties, which returned without finding anyone. One man was captured. The Messenger of Allah asked him about them, and he replied: "They fled when they heard that you had captured their livestock." The Messenger of Allah offered him Islam, and he accepted.
