Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned to Medina without encountering any opposition.

83.title: The Battle of Banu al-Mustaliq (al-Muraysi')
83.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, learned that Banu al-Mustaliq – who were a clan from the Azd Yamani tribe of Khuza'ah – were gathering to fight him. Their leader was Al-Harith ibn Abi Dirar. When the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, heard about them, he marched out to meet them until he encountered them at a watering place of theirs called al-Muraysi'. This is why this expedition is also called the Expedition of al-Muraysi'. The people advanced and fought, and God defeated Banu al-Mustaliq, killing those who were killed among them. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, took their sons, women, and wealth as spoils of war, which God granted him. Among those taken captive was Juwayriyah, may God be pleased with her, the daughter of Al-Harith ibn Abi Dirar, the chief of Banu al-Mustaliq. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, married her when she came to him seeking his help in her manumission contract. He made forty captives from her people her dowry, and the people freed those captives they held because of the status of Juwayriyah, may God be pleased with her. During the return journey from this expedition, the people of slander spoke what they spoke concerning the Mother of the Believers, Aisha, may God be pleased with her, the truthful daughter of the truthful one, who was exonerated from above the seven heavens. In this expedition also, Ibn Ubayy ibn Salul said his statement: "If we return to Medina, the mighty will expel the lowly from it!" Zayd ibn Arqam heard him, and the chapter "Al-Munafiqun" was revealed.

84.title: The Battle of the Trench (The Confederates)
84.details:
The cause of this Ghazwah was the expulsion of the Jews of Banu Nadir from Medina. Envy and malice had taken hold of their hearts, causing them to harbor enmity and seek opportunities for revenge against those who had driven them out of Medina and its surroundings. When the Jews of Khaybar, especially Banu Nadir, could not confront the Muslims, they resorted to cunning and incitement. Ibn Ishaq mentioned, with his chain of narration from a group, that those who incited the Confederates were a group of Jews, including: Sallam bin Abi al-Huqayq, Huyayy bin Akhtab al-Nadari, Kinanah bin Abi al-Huqayq al-Nadari, Hawdha bin Qays al-Wa'ili, and Abu Ammar al-Wa'ili, along with a group from Banu Nadir. When they approached Quraysh, they invited them to war against the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: "We will be with you against him until we uproot him." Quraysh said to them: "O assembly of Jews, you are the people of the first Scripture and have knowledge of what we and Muhammad differ about. Is our religion better or his?" They replied: "Rather, your religion is better than his, and you are more deserving of the truth than he!!!"

The scholars differed on the timing of this Ghazwah. Bukhari leaned towards the opinion of Musa bin Uqbah that it occurred in Shawwal in the fourth year (of Hijra), while the vast majority held that it was in the fifth year. Al-Dhahabi said: "This is the established view." Ibn al-Qayyim said: "This is the more correct opinion."

The Prophet (peace be upon him) and his companions (may Allah be pleased with them) dug a trench in the exposed area in front of the invaders. Ibn Uqbah mentioned that digging the trench took nearly twenty nights. Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went out to the trench, and the Muhajirun and Ansar were digging on a cold morning. They had no slaves to do this for them. When he saw their exhaustion and hunger, he said: 'O Allah, verily, life is the life of the Hereafter, so forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirah.' They responded to him, saying: 'We are those who have pledged allegiance to Muhammad... to strive in jihad as long as we live, forever.'"

Al-Bara' (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: "When it was the day of the Confederates, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) dug the trench, I saw him carrying dirt from the trench, until the dust covered the skin of his stomach. He was a man with much hair. I heard him reciting the words of Ibn Rawahah, as he carried the dirt, saying: 'By Allah, if not for You, we would not have been guided, nor would we have given charity, nor would we have prayed. So send down tranquility upon us, and make our feet firm if we meet the enemy. Indeed, those who have wronged us have rebelled against us, and if they intended to try us, we would refuse.'" He said: "Then he would extend his voice with the last part of it."

Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said regarding the verse: "{When they came upon you from above you and from below you, and when eyes shifted and hearts reached the throats...}" (Quran 33:10), "That was the day of the trench."

When the Confederates reached Medina, they were surprised by the presence of the trench, and they made several attempts to breach it, but they failed. The siege lasted for twenty-four nights. The situation became difficult for Quraysh due to the wind that overturned their cooking pots and tents. The Muslims also sowed discord between the Jews and the polytheists, forcing them to retreat. Allah the Almighty defeated them and averted their evil from Medina.

85.title: The revelation of the verse of the hijab.
85.details: The reason for its revelation was that Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him: "If you would order your wives to veil themselves, for indeed, the righteous and the wicked speak to them." Then the Almighty's saying was revealed: "O you who have believed, do not enter the houses of the Prophet except when you are permitted..." to His saying: "...And when you ask of them [his wives] any material thing, ask them from beyond a partition. That is purer for your hearts and their hearts."

86.title: The Battle of the Banu Qurayza Jews.
86.details: This expedition occurred immediately after the Battle of the Trench. Its cause was the breach of the covenant by Banu Qurayzah with the Prophet, peace be upon him, instigated by Huyayy ibn Akhtab an-Nadri. The Prophet, peace be upon him, had sent Zubayr to ascertain their intentions, and then followed him with the two Sa'ds – Sa'd ibn Ubadah and Sa'd ibn Mu'adh – and Ibn Rawahah, and Khawwat ibn Jubayr, for the same purpose, to confirm their treachery. Allah the Almighty commanded His Prophet, peace be upon him, to fight them after his return from the Trench and laying down of arms. So, the Prophet, peace be upon him, instructed his companions to proceed to Banu Qurayzah, saying to them: "Let none of you pray the Asr prayer except in Banu Qurayzah." This is according to the narration of Bukhari, or "Dhuhr" according to the narration of Muslim. The Messenger, peace be upon him, then besieged Banu Qurayzah for approximately twenty-five nights, until they submitted to the judgment of the Messenger, peace be upon him. He wished to entrust their judgment to one of the chiefs of Aws, as they were allies of Banu Qurayzah. Thus, he made Sa'd ibn Mu'adh the judge over them. When he approached the Muslims, the Messenger, peace be upon him, said to the Ansar: "Stand up for your chief – or your best." Then he said: "These have submitted to your judgment." Sa'd ibn Mu'adh said: "Their fighting men shall be killed, their women and children shall be taken captive, and their wealth shall be divided." The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: "You have judged with the judgment of Allah the Almighty." The Messenger, peace be upon him, carried out this judgment upon them. They were approximately four hundred in number. Only a few of them escaped. Then the Messenger, peace be upon him, divided their wealth and their children among the Muslims.

87.title: The killing of Sallam ibn Abi al-Huqayq, the Jew.
87.details:
He is Abu Rafi', Salam bin Abi al-Huqayq, a Jewish poet and knight, one of those who mobilized the factions against the Muslims in the Battle of the Confederates. He aided them with abundant provisions and wealth. When Allah killed Ka'b bin al-Ashraf at the hands of men from the Aws after the Battle of Badr, Abu Rafi', Salam bin Abi al-Huqayq was among those who incited the Confederates against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He was not killed with Banu Qurayza as his companion Huyayy bin Akhtab was. The Khazraj desired to kill him, seeking to equalize the Aws in reward. Allah, Glorified and Exalted, had made these two tribes compete in good deeds before the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. They sought permission from the Messenger of Allah to kill him, and he granted them permission.

Al-Bara' bin Azib narrated: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent some men from the Ansar to Abu Rafi' the Jew. He appointed Abdullah bin Atik as their leader. Abu Rafi' used to harm the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and aid against him. He was in a fortress of his in the land of Hijaz. When they approached him, the sun had set, and people were returning with their livestock. Abdullah said to his companions: "Sit where you are, for I am going to approach and try to get close to the gatekeeper, perhaps I can enter." He approached until he was near the gate. Then he covered himself with his garment as if he was relieving himself. As people were entering, the gatekeeper called out to him: "O Abdullah, if you want to enter, then enter, for I am about to close the gate." So I entered and hid. When the people entered, he closed the gate, then hung the locks on a peg. He said: "I went to the keys and took them, and opened the gate." Abu Rafi' used to have evening gatherings. He was in an upper chamber. When his guests left, I went up to him. As I opened each door, I locked it behind me from the inside. I said: "If the people realize I am here, they will not be able to reach me until I kill him." I reached him, and he was in a dark room amidst his family. I did not know where he was in the room. I said: "O Abu Rafi'," he said: "Who is this?" I moved towards the voice and struck him with a sword, in my bewilderment. It did not avail him, and he cried out. I left the room and stayed a short distance away, then I returned to him and said: "What is this sound, O Abu Rafi'?" He said: "Woe to your mother, a man was in the room and struck me with a sword before." He said: "I struck him a blow that wounded him deeply but did not kill him. Then I placed the tip of the sword in his belly until it went through his back. I knew then that I had killed him. I began to open the doors, one by one, until I reached a staircase. I placed my foot, thinking I had reached the ground, and fell on a moonlit night. My leg broke. I tied it with my turban, then I set off until I sat by the door. I said: 'I will not leave tonight until I know if I have killed him.' When the rooster crowed, the announcer stood on the wall and said: 'I announce the death of Abu Rafi', the merchant of the people of Hijaz.' I went to my companions and said: 'Escape! Allah has killed Abu Rafi'.' I went to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and told him. He said: 'Stretch out your leg.' I stretched out my leg, and he wiped it, and it was as if I had never complained of it."

88.title: The Battle of Dhu Qarad.
88.details: 'Uyaynah ibn Hisn, among the Banu Abd Allah ibn Ghaṭfan, raided the she-camels of the Prophet, peace be upon him, which were grazing in al-Ghaba. He seized them and killed their shepherd, a man from Ghifar, and they took his wife. The first to raise the alarm against them was Salamah ibn Amr ibn al-Akwa', al-Aslami, may Allah be pleased with him. Salamah said: "I went out before the first call to prayer. The she-camels of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, were grazing at Dhi Qarad. He said: 'A slave of Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf met me and said: "The she-camels of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, have been taken." I asked: "Who took them?" He said: "Ghaṭfan." He said: "So I cried out three times, 'Oh, morning!' I made my voice heard between the two lava fields of Medina. Then I set off at full speed until I caught up with them at Dhi Qarad, as they were beginning to drink from the water. I started pelting them with my arrows, for I was a good archer, and I said: 'I am the son of al-Akwa'... and today is the day of the sucklings.'" I recited poetry until I rescued the she-camels from them, and I took thirty cloaks from them. He said: "Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the people came. I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I have prevented the people from the water while they were thirsty, so send them now.' He said: 'O son of al-Akwa', you have gained possession, so be lenient.' Then he said: 'They are now being hosted by Ghaṭfan.'" The cry for help in Medina reached the Banu Amr ibn Awf, and reinforcements came. Horses continued to arrive, and men on foot and on camels until they reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, at Dhi Qarad. The Prophet, peace be upon him, reached a watering place called Dhi Qarad. He slaughtered a she-camel from those he had recovered and stayed there for a day and a night, then returned to Medina. In this raid, al-Akhram, who was Muhriz ibn Nadlah, may Allah be pleased with him, was killed. Abd al-Rahman ibn 'Uyaynah killed him and rode away on his horse. Abu Qatadah then charged him and killed him, and recovered the horse, which had belonged to Mahmud ibn Maslamah. The captive woman came on a she-camel of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, having vowed that if Allah saved her upon it, she would slaughter it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "What a bad reward she has given! A person has no vow for what he does not own, nor for disobedience." And he took back his she-camel. Muslim narrated in his Sahih from Salamah ibn al-Akwa' concerning this incident, saying: "We returned to Medina, and we stayed only three nights until we went out to Khaybar."

89.title: The expedition of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Qurata.
89.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may Allah be pleased with him, with thirty riders to Al-Qurṭāʾ – a seven-night journey from Medina. They were a clan of Banu Bakr, and their leader was ʿUbayd ibn Kilāb. Muhammad ibn Maslamah and his companions set out, traveling by night and hiding during the day. When they raided them, the rest fled after Muhammad killed a number of them. The Muslims seized camels and sheep and arrived in Medina on the last night of Muḥarram, bringing with them Thumamah ibn Uthāl al-Ḥanafī, the chief of Banu Ḥanīfah. He had gone out in disguise to assassinate the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, by the order of Musaylimah the Liar. The Muslims captured him, and when they brought him, they tied him to one of the pillars of the Mosque. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, went out to him and said, "What do you have, O Thumamah?" He replied, "I have good, O Muhammad. If you kill, you kill one who has blood [to avenge]. If you bestow favor, you bestow it upon one who is grateful. And if you desire wealth, ask, and you will be given whatever you wish." So he left him. Then he passed by him again and said the same thing to him, and he replied as he had before. Then he passed by a third time and, after the previous conversation, said, "Release Thumamah." So they released him. He went to a palm grove near the Mosque, bathed, then came and embraced Islam. He said, "By Allah, there was no face on the face of the earth more hateful to me than your face, but now your face has become the most beloved of faces to me. And by Allah, there was no religion on the face of the earth more hateful to me than your religion, but now your religion has become the most beloved of religions to me. Your cavalry captured me while I intended to perform ʿUmrah." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gave him glad tidings and ordered him to perform ʿUmrah. When he arrived among the Quraysh, they said, "Have you apostatized, O Thumamah?" He said, "No, by Allah, but I have embraced Islam with Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. And by Allah, not a single grain of wheat will come to you from Yamāmah unless the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, permits it." Yamāmah was the fertile region of Mecca. He returned to his land and prevented the transport of goods to Mecca until the Quraysh were in dire straits. They wrote to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, imploring him by their kinship ties to write to Thumamah to allow them to transport food. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did so.

90.title: The expedition of Ukashah ibn Mihsan (may Allah be pleased with him) to al-Ghamr (the water of Banu Asad).
90.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Ukkasha ibn Mihsan, may Allah be pleased with him, to Al-Ghamr – a water source belonging to Banu Asad – with forty men, including Thabit ibn Aqram and Shuja ibn Wahb. They set out quickly, but the people were alerted and fled to the higher ground of their land. He found their dwellings empty, meaning their inhabitants were absent. He then sent Shuja ibn Wahb as a scout. He saw tracks of camels and sheep. They moved on and found someone who guided them to some of their livestock. They granted him safety, and he led them to camels belonging to his cousins. They raided them and seized two hundred camels. They sent the man back and drove the camels to Medina. They arrived at the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, without encountering any harm.

91.title: The expedition of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Tha'labah and Banu 'Awal at Dhi al-Qassah.
91.details: The Messenger of God, Muhammad, peace be upon him, sent Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may God be pleased with him, along with ten men, to Banu Tha'labah of Ghatafan and Banu 'Awalin of Tha'labah, who were at Dhi al-Qassah. They arrived upon them at night, and the people surrounded them. They were one hundred men. They exchanged arrows for a while during the night, then the Arabs attacked them with spears and killed them all. Muhammad ibn Maslamah fell wounded. They struck his ankle, and he did not move, so they thought he was dead. They stripped him of his clothes and left. A Muslim man passed by Muhammad and his companions and uttered "Indeed, to God we belong and to Him we shall return." When Muhammad heard him saying this, he moved. The man took him and carried him to Medina. At that point, the Messenger of God, Muhammad, peace be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah with forty men to the place where they fell. They found no one, but they found camels and sheep, and they drove them to Medina.

92.title: The expedition of Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah to Dhi al-Qassah.
92.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah, may God be pleased with him, to Dhi al-Qassah – a place near Medina – in the aftermath of the killing of the companions of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may God be pleased with him, along with forty Muslims, as they were performing the Maghrib prayer. He marched to them on foot until they reached Dhi al-Qassah at the break of dawn – the remaining darkness of the night. They raided them, but they escaped into the mountains, eluding them. They captured one man who embraced Islam, so they left him. They also seized some of their livestock and scattered household items. They brought these back to Medina. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, took one-fifth of the spoils and distributed the rest among them. Ibn Sa'd states in his Tabaqat that the reason for sending Abu Ubaidah, may God be pleased with him, to Dhi al-Qassah was the news that Banu Muharib ibn Khasfah, Tha'labah, and Anmar – who are from Ghatafan – had agreed to raid the livestock of Medina as it grazed at Hayfa, a place seven miles from Medina. It is possible that the Messenger, peace be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah, may God be pleased with him, to Dhi al-Qassah twice, or that the expedition was a single event with two reasons: to avenge the slain companions of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may God be pleased with him, and to repel those who intended to raid the livestock of Medina.

93.title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Jumum (a watering place on the road to Mecca).
93.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Sulaym. He traveled until he reached al-Jamum – which is a watering place on the road to Mecca, to the left of Batn Nakhla. There, they encountered a woman from Muzaynah, named Halimah. She guided them to a settlement of Banu Sulaym. In that settlement, they seized camels, sheep, and captives. Among the captives was the husband of Halimah al-Muzayniyyah. When Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, returned to Medina with what he had acquired, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, granted Halimah herself and her husband to her.

94.title: The Expedition against Banu Lihyan (who betrayed on the Day of Ar-Raj'i).
94.details: Banu Lihyan: They were the ones who betrayed Khubayb ibn Adi, may Allah be pleased with him, and his companions on the Day of Ar-Raji. Since their lands extended deep into the Hijaz region, bordering Mecca, and due to existing feuds between the Muslims on one side, and Quraysh and the Bedouins on the other, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, deemed it unwise to venture into lands close to the greatest and primary enemy, Quraysh. When the confederates faltered and their resolve weakened, he saw that the time had come to raid Banu Lihyan and avenge the companions of Ar-Raji. So, the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, marched out to them with two hundred of his companions, seeking retribution for the blood of his companions, accompanied by twenty horses. He appointed Abdullah ibn Umm Maktum, may Allah be pleased with him, as his deputy in Medina. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gave the impression that he intended to go to Sham to catch Banu Lihyan by surprise. Then he hastened his march until he reached Wadi Ghurran, between Amj - a place between Mecca and Medina - and Usfan - a village between Mecca and Medina. These were the dwelling places of Banu Lihyan, and where his companions had met their fate. He prayed for mercy upon them and supplicated for them. Banu Lihyan heard of his arrival, so they fled and took refuge in the mountain peaks. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, could not reach any of them. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stayed in their land for a day or two, and sent out raiding parties in every direction, but they could not capture anyone. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, marched with his companions to Usfan, so that Quraysh would hear of it and be filled with dread, and to show them his strength. He sent Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, with ten horsemen to Kur al-Ghamim - a place between Mecca and Medina. Then Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, returned without encountering anyone.

95.title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Al-ʿĪṣ.
95.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, in a detachment of one hundred and seventy riders to Al-`Is, a place near Medina on the coast of the sea, with the aim of intercepting a caravan of Quraysh that was coming from Syria, led by Abu Al-`As ibn Al-Rabi`. They caught up with it, seized it and what was in it, and that day they took much silver belonging to Safwan ibn Umayyah. They also captured people from among those who were in the caravan, including Abu Al-`As ibn Al-Rabi`, and brought them to Medina. Abu Al-`As was among the distinguished men of Mecca in terms of trade, wealth, and trustworthiness. He was the husband of Zaynab, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. His mother was Halah bint Khuwaylid, the sister of Khadijah, may Allah be pleased with her. Abu Al-`As came to Zaynab, may Allah be pleased with her, at night. Zaynab had migrated before him, leaving him in his polytheism. He sought her protection, and she granted him protection. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, approved her protection.

96.title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah to Banu Tha'labah at al-Tarf (a watering place near Medina).
96.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Al-Taraf – which is a watering place thirty-six miles from Medina. He went out to Banu Tha'labah with fifteen men. The Arabs fled, fearing that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had marched against them, and that these men were a vanguard. He seized twenty camels from their livestock and returned to Medina without encountering any opposition. He was away for four nights. Their war cry was: "Kill, kill."

97.title: The Expedition of Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, to Dumat al-Jandal.
97.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, called Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf, may God be pleased with him, and said to him: "Prepare yourself, for I am sending you on a mission from this day, or tomorrow if God Almighty wills." Abd al-Rahman awoke and went to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, who seated him before him and turbaned him with his own hand. Then the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, tied the banner with his own hand, or ordered Bilal to hand it to him, and then said to him: "Take it in the name of God and His blessings." Then he praised God Almighty, and then the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "Go forth in the name of God and in the cause of God, and fight those who disbelieve in God! Do not commit treachery – treachery is betrayal in spoils of war and theft from the booty before distribution – do not break your covenant, and do not kill a child." Then the Messenger of God ordered him to march to the tribe of Banu Kalb in Dumat al-Jandal, and to invite them to Islam. He said to him: "If they respond to you, then marry their king's daughter." Abd al-Rahman, may God be pleased with him, marched with his companions, who numbered seven hundred men, until he reached Dumat al-Jandal. He stayed there for three days, inviting them to Islam. When the third day came, their chief and king, al-Asbagh ibn Amr al-Kalbi, who was a Christian, embraced Islam, and many of his people embraced Islam with him. Abd al-Rahman then sent Rafi' ibn Makith as a bearer of good news to the Prophet, peace be upon him, informing him of the victory God had granted him and writing to him about it. Abd al-Rahman married Tamadir bint al-Asbagh and brought her to Medina. She later bore him Abu Salamah ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf.

98.title: The expedition of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Fazara in Wadi al-Qura.
98.details: The clan of Fazara intended to assassinate the Prophet, peace be upon him. So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may God be pleased with him. They raided them, killing, capturing, and taking spoils. Among their notorious figures was Umm Qirfa, who had prepared thirty horsemen from her household to assassinate the Messenger of God, peace be upon him. They were killed, and her daughter was captured. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, ransomed some Muslim captives in Mecca with her. Imam Muslim narrated in his Sahih from Salamah bin Al-Akwa', may God be pleased with him, who said: "We went on an expedition against Fazara, and Abu Bakr was our commander, appointed by the Messenger of God, peace be upon him. When we were an hour away from the water, Abu Bakr ordered us to encamp. Then he launched the raid and reached the water. He killed those he killed there and took captives. I saw a group of people, including children, and I feared they would reach the mountain before me, so I shot an arrow between them and the mountain. When they saw the arrow, they stopped. I brought them, driving them. Among them was a woman from Banu Fazara wearing a garment of tanned leather (meaning a leather garment), with her was a daughter, one of the most beautiful Arab women. I drove them until I brought them to Abu Bakr, and Abu Bakr gave me her daughter as a spoil. When we arrived in Medina, I had not uncovered her. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, met me in the market and said: 'O Salamah, gift me the woman.' I said: 'O Messenger of God, by God, she has pleased me, and I have not uncovered her.' The next day, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, met me again in the market and said to me: 'O Salamah, gift me the woman, may your father be sacrificed for you!' I said: 'She is yours, O Messenger of God, and by God, I have not uncovered her.' So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent her to the people of Mecca, and with her, he ransomed some Muslims who had been captured in Mecca."

99.title: The Expedition of Kurz ibn Jabir al-Fihri to the 'Arniyyin.
99.details:
In this year, the expedition of Kurz ibn Jabir al-Fihri took place against the Uraynah tribe. These were the ones who killed the shepherd of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and drove away the livestock. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Kurz ibn Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, with twenty horsemen in pursuit of them.

Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that a group from Ukl and Uraynah came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and said: "We are people of milk-producing animals, and we are not people of fertile land. The climate of Medina did not suit us." So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered for them a herd of camels and a shepherd, and instructed them to go out with them and drink from their urine and milk. They set off, and when they reached the area of Al-Harrah, they killed the shepherd of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and drove away the herd. They renounced Islam after having embraced it.

The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent out in pursuit of them. He ordered that their hands and feet be cut off, and their eyes be branded with hot iron nails. He left them in the area of Al-Harrah until they died in that state. The reason their eyes were branded was because they had branded the eyes of the shepherds.

100.title: The Pledge of Ridwan.
100.details:
Before the conclusion of the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had sent Khirash ibn Umayyah al-Khuzai to Mecca, riding his camel named al-Tha'lab. When he entered Mecca, Quraysh hamstrung his camel and intended to kill Khirash, but the Ahābīsh (who were Banu al-Harith ibn Abd Manah ibn Kinanah, al-Hawn ibn Khuzaymah ibn Mudrikah, and Banu al-Mustaliq from Khuzā'ah) prevented them until he reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He then called for Umar to send him to Mecca. Umar said, "O Messenger of Allah, I fear Quraysh for myself, and there is no one from Banu Adi here to protect me. Quraysh know my enmity towards them and my harshness against them. However, I can direct you to a man who is more honored than I, Uthman ibn Affan." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, called for Uthman and sent him to Quraysh to inform them that he had not come for war, but as a visitor to this House, honoring its sanctity. Uthman set out until he reached Mecca, where Aban ibn Sa'id ibn al-'As met him. Aban dismounted his mount, placed Uthman before him and behind him on his mount, and gave him protection until he delivered the message of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Uthman then went to Abu Sufyan and the dignitaries of Quraysh and conveyed to them what the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had sent him with. They said to Uthman, "If you wish, you may circumambulate the Kaaba." He replied, "I would not do so until the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, circumambulates it." Quraysh then detained him. It reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and the Muslims that Uthman had been killed.

Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Pledge of Ridwan took place after Uthman had gone to Mecca. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, placed his right hand on his left hand and said, "This is the hand of Uthman," and struck it with his hand, saying, "This is for Uthman." Jabir ibn Abdullah said: On the day of Hudaybiyyah, we were one thousand and four hundred. We pledged allegiance to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and Umar was holding his hand under the tree, which was a samurah tree. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to us, "Today, you are the best people on earth." Then Jabir said: If I were able to see, I would show you the location of the tree.

Ma'qil ibn Yasar said: I saw myself on the day of the tree, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, was taking the pledge from the people, and I was holding up a branch of it over his head, and we were fourteen hundred.

The narrations differ regarding their number. Ibn Hajar said: The reconciliation between these differences is that they were more than one thousand and four hundred. Whoever said one thousand and five hundred accounted for the fraction, and whoever said one thousand and four hundred disregarded it.

101.title: The Treaty of Hudaybiyyah.
101.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, went out with about fourteen hundred of his companions, intending to perform Umrah. When they reached Al-Hudaybiyyah, which is about 22 km from Mecca, news reached him that there were those who intended to fight him. He said: "I have not come for fighting; rather, I have come for Umrah." The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Uthman ibn Affan to Mecca to inform them of this. Then the news spread that Uthman had been killed. So the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, ordered the companions, may God be pleased with them, to pledge allegiance to him for fighting, and they pledged allegiance to him. This was the Pledge of Ridwan. Then the polytheists came to Al-Hudaybiyyah, and several negotiations took place between the leaders of the polytheists and the Prophet, peace be upon him, until Suhail ibn Amr came, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, made peace with him on the condition that war would be suspended for ten years, during which people would be safe and refrain from harming each other. It was also agreed that whoever came to the Messenger of God from his companions without the permission of his guardian, the Messenger of God would return him to them, and whoever came to the Quraysh from his companions, they would not return him. And that there would be a sealed chest between them, meaning no deceit. And that there would be no stealing or treachery. And that he would return in this year without entering Mecca, but he would be allowed to enter it for three days in the following year, with the weapons of a traveler, and not to enter it without swords in their sheaths. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, ordered his companions to sacrifice their animals and shave their heads, but they did not do so until Umm Salamah, may God be pleased with her, advised him to do it himself without speaking to anyone. When they saw him sacrifice, they rushed to the sacrificial animals and did the same. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, returned to Medina without performing Umrah and without fighting.

102.title: The Battle of Khaybar.
102.details:
The historians differ regarding its timing, with two opinions. It was said: in the seventh year. This is the opinion of Ibn Ishaq and others. And it was said: in the sixth year. This is the opinion of Malik and others. Ibn al-Qayyim said: The majority hold that it was in the seventh year. Ibn Hajar said: These opinions are close, and the most likely among them is what Ibn Ishaq mentioned. It is possible to reconcile them by saying that whoever stated the sixth year did so based on the beginning of the year from the actual month of the Hijra, which is Rabi' al-Awwal.

Anas narrated: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went on an expedition to Khaybar. He said: "We prayed the dawn prayer there in the early morning darkness. Then the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, mounted, and Abu Talha mounted, and I was riding behind Abu Talha. The Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, rode through a narrow alley of Khaybar, and my knee was touching the thigh of the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him. The lower garment of the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, slipped, and I saw the whiteness of the thigh of the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him. When he entered the town, he said: 'Allahu Akbar! Khaybar is ruined! When we descend upon a people's courtyard, then it is a bad morning for those who are warned.' He said this three times. He said: The people had gone out to their work, and they said: 'Muhammad! By Allah!' (Abdul Aziz said: And some of our companions said: 'Muhammad and the army'). He said: 'And we conquered it by force. The captives were gathered. Then Dihya came to him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, give me a slave girl from the captives.' He said: 'Go and take a slave girl.' So he took Safiyyah bint Huyayy. Then a man came to the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, and said: 'O Prophet of Allah, you gave Safiyyah bint Huyayy, the chief of Qurayzah and an-Nadir, to Dihya! She is only fit for you.' He said: 'Call him with her.' He said: 'So he brought her. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, looked at her, he said: 'Take a slave girl from the captives other than her.' He said: 'And he freed her and married her...'"

Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to Khaybar. He came to it at night. When he came to a people at night, he would not attack them until morning. When morning came, the Jews came out with their shovels and baskets. When they saw him, they said: "Muhammad! By Allah! Muhammad and the army!" Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Allahu Akbar! Khaybar is ruined! When we descend upon a people's courtyard, then it is a bad morning for those who are warned." And Allah Almighty made the conquest of Khaybar at the hands of Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him.

Abdullah ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, gave Khaybar to the Jews to work it and cultivate it, and they would have half of what came out of it. So the Prophet, peace be upon him, let them remain in their land, and they would have half.

103.title: The prohibition of the flesh of domestic donkeys and the temporary marriage of women on the day of Khaybar.
103.details: During the Battle of Khaybar, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prohibited the meat of domestic donkeys, stating that it was an impurity. He ordered that the pots be thrown away while they were boiling with their meat, and he later ordered the pots to be washed. At that time, he permitted the meat of horses and fed it to them. He also prohibited temporary marriage (mut'ah) of women.

104.title: The Hijra of Abu Musa al-Ash'ari and his companions, may Allah be pleased with them, to Medina, passing through Abyssinia.
104.details: Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: News of the departure of the Prophet (peace be upon him) reached us while we were in Yemen. So, my two brothers and I, I being the youngest, set out as emigrants to him. One of them was Abu Burda, and the other was Abu Ruhm. He said, "Either in a few, or he said, in fifty-three, or fifty-two men from my people." We boarded a ship, and our ship cast us ashore to the Negus in Abyssinia. We met Ja'far bin Abi Talib and his companions there. Ja'far said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent us here and commanded us to stay, so stay with us." We stayed with him until we all arrived. We met the Prophet (peace be upon him) when he conquered Khaybar. He gave us a share of it – or he said, he gave us from it. He did not distribute anything from it to anyone who was absent from the conquest of Khaybar, except to those who witnessed it with him, except for the companions of our ship with Ja'far and his companions; he distributed to them along with them.

105.title: The Jews' attempt to poison the Messenger of God, peace be upon him.
105.details: When the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, felt secure in Khaybar after its conquest, Zaynab bint al-Harith, the wife of Sallam ibn Mishkam, presented him with a roasted sheep. She had inquired which part of the sheep the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, preferred, and was told it was the foreleg. She then put a large amount of poison in it, and also poisoned the rest of the sheep. She brought it to him, and when she placed it before the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, he took the foreleg and chewed a morsel from it, but he could not swallow it and spat it out. Then he said, "This bone informs me that it is poisoned." He then called for her, and she confessed. He asked, "What drove you to do this?" She replied, "I thought if he were a king, we would be rid of him, and if he were a prophet, he would be informed." He pardoned her. Bishr ibn al-Bara' ibn Ma'rur was with him and ate a portion of it, which he swallowed. He died from it. There are differing narrations regarding the pardon of the woman and her execution. They agree that he initially pardoned her, but when Bishr died, he killed her in retribution.

106.title: The Prophet's correspondence with the kings, inviting them to Islam.
106.details: After the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, returned from Al-Hudaybiyyah, he wrote to the kings, inviting them to Islam. When he intended to write to them, it was said to him, "They do not read a letter unless it has a seal on it." So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, took a silver ring, the engraving of which was: "Muhammad, Messenger of Allah." This engraving was in three lines: "Muhammad" on one line, "Messenger" on another, and "Allah" on a third. Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I can almost see the gleam of the ring on the Prophet's finger - or on his palm." He chose messengers from his companions who had knowledge and experience and sent them to the kings. He sent Dihyah bin Khalifa Al-Kalbi to Caesar, the King of Rome, who read the letter but did not embrace Islam. He sent Abdullah bin Hudhafah As-Sahmi to Khosrow, the King of Persia, who tore the letter to pieces when it was read to him. When this reached the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "May Allah tear his kingdom apart." And so it was. He sent Amr bin Umayyah Ad-Damri to Al-Najashi, the King of Abyssinia. When he gave him the letter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he took it, placed it on his eyes, and descended from his throne to the ground. He sent Hatib bin Abi Balta'ah to Al-Muqawqis, the ruler of Alexandria. He took the Prophet's letter, placed it in an ivory box, sealed it, and then wrote a letter to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, but did not embrace Islam. He gifted him two slave women, Maria and Shireen, and a mule named Dul-dul. He sent Amr bin Al-As As-Sahmi to Ja'far and 'Abbad, the sons of Al-Julanda Al-Azdiyyin, the kings of Oman. They both responded to Islam and believed in the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. He sent Sulait bin Amr, one of the Bani Amir bin Lu'ayy, to Hawdha bin Ali Al-Hanafi, the King of Yamamah, who gave a lukewarm response. He wrote to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "How excellent and beautiful is what you call to. The Arabs respect my position, so grant me some authority and I will follow you." He sent Al-Ala' bin Al-Hadrami to Al-Mundhir bin Sawa Al-Abdi, the King of Bahrain, who embraced Islam upon receiving the letter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. He sent Shuja' bin Wahb Al-Asadi to Al-Harith bin Abi Shimr Al-Ghassani, the King of the Syrian borders. When the letter reached him, he threw it away and said, "Who will take my kingdom from me? I am marching to him." He did not embrace Islam. He sought permission from Caesar to fight the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, but Caesar dissuaded him from his resolve. Al-Harith, however, rewarded Shuja' bin Wahb with clothing and provisions and sent him back with kindness. He sent Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad Al-Makhzumi to Al-Harith bin Abd Kulal Al-Himayri, the King of Yemen, who had already embraced Islam along with his brothers.

107.title: The expedition of Ghalib ibn Abdullah al-Laythi to the Banu al-Mulawwah at Qudayd.
107.details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, sent a detachment led by Ghalib ibn Abdullah al-Laythi to the Banu al-Mulawwah in Qudayd. The Banu al-Mulawwah had killed the companions of Bashir ibn Suwayd, so this detachment was sent to exact revenge. They launched a night raid, killing whom they killed and seizing livestock. A large enemy army pursued them until, as they neared the Muslims, rain fell, and a great flood came between the two groups. The Muslims succeeded in completing their withdrawal.

108.title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah to the land of Hisma.
108.details: The Messenger, peace be upon him, sent a letter to Caesar of Rome. The bearer of the letter was Dihyah ibn Khalifah al-Kalbi. When Caesar did what he did, he rewarded Dihyah ibn Khalifah al-Kalbi with money and clothing. As Dihyah was on the road in Hisma, some people from Judham encountered him and robbed him, leaving him with nothing. Dihyah came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, before entering his house and informed him. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah to Hisma, which is beyond Wadi al-Qura, with five hundred men. Zayd launched a raid against Judham, killing many of them and seizing their camels, sheep, and captives. He took a thousand camels, five thousand sheep, and one hundred women and children as captives. There was a truce between the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the tribe of Judham. Zayd ibn Rifaa'ah al-Judhami, one of the leaders of this tribe, quickly presented a protest to the Prophet, peace be upon him. He and some men from his people had embraced Islam and had helped Dihyah when his way was blocked. The Prophet, peace be upon him, accepted his protest and ordered the return of the spoils and the captives.

109.title: The expedition of Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, to Turbah, a group of Hawazin.
109.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, with thirty men to the rear of Hawazin – a place between him and Mecca, four nights away on the road to Sana'a, called Turbah. And Allah's peace be upon him sent a guide from Banu Hilal. He would travel by night and hide by day. The news reached Hawazin, so they fled. Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, came to their encampments and found no one from them, so he returned to Medina. When he was six miles between him and Medina, the guide said to him, "Do you have another gathering from Khath'am?" Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said to him, "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not order me to [fight] them; he only ordered me to fight Hawazin."

110.title: The expedition of Bashir ibn Sa'd al-Ansari to Banu Murrah in the region of Fadak.
110.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Bashir ibn Sa'd al-Ansari to Banu Murrah in the vicinity of Fadak, consisting of thirty men. They went out to them and seized sheep and camels. Then they returned, and the pursuers caught up with them at night. They shot arrows at them until Bashir and his companions ran out of arrows, and they were all killed except for Bashir. He was carried to Fadak with a flicker of life remaining, and he stayed with the Jews until his wounds healed, then he returned to Medina.

111.title: The expedition of Ghalib ibn Abd Allah al-Laythi to Banu Uwal.
111.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Ghalib ibn Abd Allah al-Laythi to Banu 'Uwal and Banu 'Abd ibn Tha'labah in al-Mayfa'ah, and it is said to the Hurqat of Juhaynah, consisting of one hundred and thirty men. They raided them all, killed those who came out to them, and seized camels and sheep. In this detachment, Usamah ibn Zayd killed Nahik ibn Mirdas after he said, "There is no god but Allah." When they returned and the Prophet, peace be upon him, was informed, he was greatly displeased and said, "Did you kill him after he said, 'There is no god but Allah'?" Usamah replied, "He only said it seeking refuge." The Prophet then said, "Did you not split open his heart to know if he was truthful or lying?"

112.title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Rawahah to Khaybar to kill the Jew Yassir ibn Razzam.
112.details: It reached the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, that Yasir bin Rizam the Jew was gathering Ghatafan to invade Medina. So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Abdullah bin Rawahah with thirty riders to Yasir bin Rizam until they reached him in Khaybar. They said to him: "The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, has sent us to you to appoint you over Khaybar." They persisted with him until he followed them with thirty men, each man accompanied by a Muslim rider. When they reached Qarqaratu Niyar, Yasir bin Rizam regretted it and reached for the sword of Abdullah bin Rawahah. Abdullah bin Rawahah noticed this, urged his camel forward, and charged, leading the men until he was able to reach Yasir and struck his leg, severing it. Yasir then charged, and in his hand was a whip made of acacia wood, with which he struck Abdullah bin Rawahah's face, inflicting a severe wound that reached the skull. Each of the Muslim men turned to his rider and killed him, except for one Jew who outran them in speed and did not harm any of the Muslims. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, spat into Abdullah bin Rawahah's wound, and it did not fester or cause him pain until he died.

113.title: The expedition of Abu Hadrad al-Aslami to al-Ghaba.
113.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Abu Hadrad al-Aslami to al-Ghaba. The reason for this was that a man from Jusham ibn Mu'awiyah had arrived in al-Ghaba with a large number of people, intending to rally Qays to fight the Muslims. So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Abu Hadrad with two men to gather intelligence and information about them. They reached the people at sunset. Abu Hadrad hid in one area, and his companions hid in another. Their shepherd was delayed until the darkness of night fell. The leader of the people then stood up alone. As he passed by Abu Hadrad, Abu Hadrad shot him with an arrow in the heart, and he fell without speaking. Abu Hadrad then beheaded him and rushed towards the camp, shouting "Allahu Akbar." His companions also shouted "Allahu Akbar" and rushed forward. The people had no choice but to flee, and the three Muslims drove off a large number of camels and sheep.

114.title: The Umrah of Hudaybiyyah, also known as the Umrah of Fulfillment.
114.details: Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions arrived in Mecca, weakened by the fever of Yathrib. The polytheists said: "Tomorrow, a people will come to you weakened by fever, having suffered greatly from it." So they sat down next to the Hijr. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered them to perform *ramal* (a brisk walk) for three circuits and to walk between the two corners, so that the polytheists would see their strength. The polytheists said: "These are the ones you claimed were weakened by fever; they are stronger than so-and-so." Ibn Abbas said: Nothing prevented him from ordering them to perform *ramal* for all the circuits except his concern for them. And in this Umrah, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, married Maymunah bint Al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with her.

115.title: The expedition of Ibn Abi al-Awja' to Banu Sulaym.
115.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent the detachment of Ibn Abi Al-Awja' to Banu Sulaym, with fifty men, to invite them to Islam. They said, "We have no need for what you have invited us to," and then they fought fiercely. Abu Al-Awja' was wounded in it, and two men from the enemy were captured.

116.title: The passing of Zaynab, may Allah be pleased with her, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.
116.details: She is Zaynab, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and the eldest of her sisters. Her cousin, Abu al-As ibn al-Rabi', married her during her mother's lifetime. She bore him Umamah, whom Ali ibn Abi Talib married after Fatima, and she bore him Ali ibn Abi al-As. Zaynab embraced Islam and migrated six years before her husband embraced Islam. Umm Atiyyah said: When Zaynab, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, died, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to us: "Wash her an odd number of times, three or five, and in the fifth time, put camphor, or something of camphor. When you finish washing her, inform me." She said: "We informed him, and he gave us his lower garment and said: 'Put it next to her skin.'"

117.title: The Expedition of Awṭās (a valley between Mecca and Ta'if).
117.details: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, finished with Hunayn, he sent Abu 'Amir with an army to Awṭas. They encountered Durayd ibn al-Ṣimmah, and Durayd was killed, and Allah defeated his companions. Abu Musa al-Ash'ari said: "Abu 'Amir 'Ubayd al-Ash'ari sent me with him. Abu 'Amir was wounded in his knee by an arrow shot by a Jushami, which struck him in the knee. I reached him and asked, 'Uncle, who shot you?' He pointed to him and said, 'That is my killer who shot me.' I went for him and caught up with him. When he saw me, he turned to flee, so I pursued him, saying, 'Are you not ashamed? Why don't you stand your ground?' He stopped, and we exchanged two sword blows, and I killed him. Then I said to Abu 'Amir, 'May Allah kill your companion.' He said, 'Pull this arrow out.' I pulled it out, and water gushed forth. He said, 'Nephew, give my greetings to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and tell him to ask for my forgiveness.' Abu 'Amir appointed me as his successor over the people. He remained for a short while and then died. I returned and entered upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, in his house. He was lying on a worn-out bed with a mattress, and the rough fibers of the bed had left marks on his back and sides. I informed him of our news and the news of Abu 'Amir. He said, 'Tell him to ask for my forgiveness.' He then called for water, performed ablution, raised his hands, and said, 'O Allah, forgive 'Ubayd, Abu 'Amir.' I saw the whiteness of his armpits. Then he said, 'O Allah, make him on the Day of Resurrection above many of Your creation among mankind.' I said, 'And appoint me, and forgive me.' He said, 'O Allah, forgive the sin of 'Abd Allah ibn Qays, and admit him on the Day of Resurrection into a noble entrance.' Abu Burda said: 'One of these supplications was for Abu 'Amir, and the other was for Abu Musa.'"

118.title: The Islam of Amr ibn al-As, Khalid ibn al-Walid, and Uthman ibn Talhah, may Allah be pleased with them.
118.details: Khalid ibn al-Walid said: "When Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, willed the good He willed for me, He cast Islam into my heart and guided my reason. I said, 'I have witnessed all these battles against Muhammad, peace be upon him, and there was no battle I witnessed except that I would leave feeling that I was in the wrong, and that Muhammad would prevail.' When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out to Hudaybiyyah, I went out with the polytheists' cavalry. I stood opposite him in 'Usfan and confronted him. He prayed the Dhuhr prayer with his companions in front of us, and we intended to raid them, but we were not able to. Then he prayed the Asr prayer with his companions, the prayer of fear, and that had a significant impact on us. I said, 'This man is protected.' So we parted ways. When he made peace with Quraysh at Hudaybiyyah, and then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, entered Mecca for the 'Umrah of Qada', he asked for me but did not find me. He wrote me a letter saying: 'In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. To proceed, I have not seen anything more astonishing than your opinion turning away from Islam and your intellect. Would anyone be ignorant of something like Islam?' Then he inquired about me, and it was said to him, 'Allah will bring him.' He said, 'Someone like him being ignorant of Islam, and if he were to strike the polytheists alongside the Muslims, it would be better for him, and we would have preferred him over others.' When his letter reached me, I was eager to go out, and it increased my desire for Islam. I was pleased that he inquired about me. When I decided to go out to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, I met Uthman ibn Talhah and offered him Islam, and he responded quickly. He went out with me until we reached al-Haddah, where we found Amr ibn al-'As. He said, 'Welcome, O people.' We said, 'And to you.' He asked, 'Where are you headed?' We said, 'To enter Islam and follow Muhammad, peace be upon him.' He said, 'And that is what brought me here.' So we accompanied each other until we entered Medina. I put on some of my best clothes, then I went to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He had been informed of our arrival and was pleased. He kept smiling when he saw me until I stood before him. I greeted him with prophethood, and he responded with a cheerful face. I said, 'I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and that you are the Messenger of Allah.' He said, 'Praise be to Allah who has guided you. I used to think you had a mind, and I hoped He would not lead you astray except to good.' I said, 'O Messenger of Allah, you have seen what I used to witness in those battles against you. So pray to Allah to forgive them for me.' The Prophet, peace be upon him, said, 'Islam erases what came before it.'"

119.title: The expedition of Ghalib ibn Abd Allah al-Laythi to the companions of Bashir ibn Sa'd at Fidak.
119.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent an expedition led by Ghalib bin Abdullah to the injured companions of Bashir bin Sa'd in Fadak, with two hundred men. They seized camels from Banu Murrah and killed some of them.

120.title: The expedition of Ka'b ibn 'Umayr al-Anṣārī to Banū Kuḍāʿah.
120.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment to Dhat Atlah under the command of Ka'b ibn 'Umayr al-Ansari with fifteen men to Banu Qudha'ah. This was because they had gathered large numbers to raid the Muslims. They encountered the enemy and invited them to Islam, but they did not respond and showered them with arrows until all of them were killed except for one man, who was recovered from among the slain.

121.title: The expedition of Shuja' ibn Wahb, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Hawazin.
121.details: The Banu Hawazin had repeatedly extended a helping hand to the enemies of the Muslims. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Shuja' ibn Wahb al-Asadi with twenty-five men to them. They were at al-Siyy, in the vicinity of Rukbah, beyond the mine, which is five nights' journey from Medina. He ordered him to raid them. So, he traveled by night and hid by day until he surprised them while they were heedless. He had instructed his companions not to pursue them excessively. They captured a large number of camels and sheep without encountering any resistance, and drove them until they arrived in Medina and divided the spoils. Each man received fifteen camels, and they valued a camel at ten sheep. Their absence lasted fifteen nights.

122.title: The Battle of Mu'tah.
122.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, dispatched a detachment of three thousand fighters, with Zayd ibn Harithah as their commander. If he were killed, then Ja'far ibn Abi Talib would take command, and if he were killed, then Abdullah ibn Rawahah would take command. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, saw them off and bid them farewell, then he returned. The army set out. When they reached Ma'an in the land of Sham, the news reached them that Heraclius, the king of Rome, had descended upon the land of Bani Ma'ab – the land of Balqa – with one hundred thousand Romans and another hundred thousand from the Christians of Sham. The Muslims stayed in Ma'an for two nights, consulting about engaging their enemy, who numbered two hundred thousand. They said, "Let us write to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, to inform him of the number of our enemy, so that he may command us or send us reinforcements." Abdullah ibn Rawahah said, "O people, what you dislike is what you set out to seek – meaning martyrdom. We do not fight people with numbers or strength; rather, we fight them with this [faith] with which God has honored us. So, march forth, for it is one of two good outcomes: either victory or martyrdom." The army agreed with this opinion and set out. When they reached the borders of Balqa, they encountered some of the legions with Heraclius near a village called Mu'tah. They fought, and Zayd ibn Harithah was killed. Ja'far ibn Abi Talib took the banner, and fought until his right hand was severed. He took the banner with his left hand, and it was severed. He then embraced it and was killed in that manner. Abdullah ibn Rawahah took the banner and hesitated for a moment before dismounting, then he resolved and fought until he was killed. Thabit ibn Aqram took the banner and said, "O Muslims, agree upon one of your own." They said, "You." He said, "No." The people agreed upon Khalid ibn al-Walid. When he took the banner, he defended the people and rallied them. Then he retreated, and they retreated with him, until he withdrew with the Muslims who were with him. Khalid ibn al-Walid said, "On the day of Mu'tah, nine swords broke in my hand, and nothing remained in my hand but a Yemeni blade." This implies that they inflicted heavy casualties upon the enemy, for otherwise, they would not have been able to extricate themselves. For this reason and others, some scholars have concluded that the Muslims were victorious in this battle and were not defeated. Anas, may God be pleased with him, reported that the Prophet, peace be upon him, informed the people of the deaths of Zayd, Ja'far, and Ibn Rawahah before their news reached them. He said, "Zayd took the banner and was struck down. Then Ja'far took it and was struck down. Then Ibn Rawahah took it and was struck down, and his eyes were shedding tears, until a sword from the swords of God took it, and God granted them victory."

123.title: The Battle of Dhat al-Salasil.
123.details:
This occurred after the Battle of Mu'tah, and it was named Dhat al-Salasil because it took place near a water source called al-Salasil. The Prophet, peace be upon him, received news that a gathering of the Quda'ah tribe had assembled and intended to approach the outskirts of Medina. The Prophet, peace be upon him, summoned Amr ibn al-'As, gave him a white banner, and dispatched him with three hundred of the prominent Emigrants and Helpers. Amr ibn al-'As, may Allah be pleased with him, was their commander. Amr said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent for me and said: "Take your clothes and your weapons, then come to me." I came to him while he was performing ablution. He looked up at me, then lowered his head, and said: "I intend to send you on a mission, and Allah will grant you safety and spoils, and I desire for you a good amount of wealth." I said: "O Messenger of Allah, I did not embrace Islam for the sake of wealth, but rather I embraced Islam out of a desire for Islam and to be with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." He said: "O Amr, good wealth is indeed good for a good man."

During the expedition, his companions asked him to light a fire, but he forbade them. They spoke to Abu Bakr, who then spoke to him about it. He said: "No one among them shall light a fire unless I throw him into it." He said: "They encountered the enemy and defeated them. They wanted to pursue them, but he forbade them. When that army returned, they mentioned this to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and complained to him. He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I disliked allowing them to light a fire lest their enemy see their small numbers, and I disliked them pursuing lest they receive reinforcements and turn back upon them.' So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, praised his decision..."

In this expedition, Amr led the people in prayer while he was in a state of ritual impurity (junub) and had water. He did not do more than wash his private parts and perform tayammum. When Amr returned to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he asked him about his prayer. Amr informed him, saying: "By Him Who sent you with the truth, if I had performed a full bath, I would have died. I have never felt cold like that before. And Allah, the Almighty, said: {And do not kill yourselves. Indeed, Allah is to you ever Merciful.} [An-Nisa: 29]." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, smiled and said nothing to him.

124.title: The expedition of Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah, may Allah be pleased with him, to the coast of the Red Sea.
124.details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah with three hundred men to the coast of the sea. The purpose of this expedition was to scout a caravan of Quraysh and to fight a tribe from Juhaynah. He provided them with a waterskin of dates, which Abu Ubaidah rationed out to them, to the point where he had to count them, giving each man one date per day. One day, when he distributed them, a date was missing for one man, and he noticed its absence that day. When their provisions ran out, they ate khabat, which is the leaves of the salim tree. The army was therefore named the "Army of Khabat." They suffered severe hunger. Qais ibn Sa'd ibn Ubadah, who was one of the soldiers in this expedition, slaughtered three young camels, then three more, and then three more. Abu Ubaidah then forbade him. The sea then cast forth an animal for them, called the 'anbar. They ate from it for twenty nights and used its fat for anointing, until their bodies recovered and improved. Abu Ubaidah took one of its ribs and measured it against the tallest man in the army and the tallest camel, and the camel was ridden under it. They also took provisions of its meat, dried in strips. When they returned to Medina, they came to the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and told him about it. He said, "It is a provision that God brought forth for you. Do you have any of its meat with you to feed us?" They sent some of it to the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and he ate it.

125.title: The expedition of Abu Qatadah al-Ansari to Khadrah.
125.details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Abu Qatadah ibn Rib'i, may Allah be pleased with him, on a raid to Khadrah. This was because the Banu Ghaftan were gathering in Khadrah, which is the land of Muharib in Najd. So, he sent him, peace and blessings be upon him, with fifteen men. They killed some of them, took captives, and acquired spoils. His absence lasted fifteen nights.

126.title: The expedition of Abu Qatadah, may Allah be pleased with him, to the valley of Idham.
126.details: When Quraysh and those with them broke the treaty between them and the Muslims at Hudaybiyyah, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, resolved to march against them. He ordered the people to prepare and informed them that he was heading to Mecca, saying: "O Allah, blind Quraysh to our movements and intelligence, so that we may surprise them in their land." To further conceal and obscure his intentions, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent a detachment of eight men, under the command of Abu Qatadah ibn al-Ribi', to Batn Idham, between Dhi Khashab and Dhi al-Marwah, three days' journey from Medina, at the beginning of this noble month. This was so that anyone who thought might assume that the Prophet, peace be upon him, was heading in that direction, and that news would spread accordingly. This detachment continued its journey until, upon reaching their assigned location, they learned that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had already departed for Mecca. They then proceeded to join him.

127.title: The Conquest of Mecca
127.details:
The reason for this was that the polytheists broke the treaty between them and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. They raided one of the tribes allied with the Messenger, peace be upon him, which was the tribe of Khuza'ah. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, learned of the matter, he ordered the people to prepare without informing them of his destination. Then he proceeded until he encamped at Marr al-Dhahrān, a valley near Mecca.

It is narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, set out from Medina in Ramadan with ten thousand men. This was eight and a half years after his arrival in Medina. He and the Muslims with him marched to Mecca, fasting and being fasted. When they reached al-Kadīd, a water source between 'Usfan and Qudayd, he broke his fast, and they broke theirs.

Abu Sufyan had seen the army of the Prophet, peace be upon him, before their entry into Mecca, and was terrified by what he saw. He then embraced Islam. After that, he went to his people and cried out to them, warning them that they had no strength against the army of Muhammad, peace be upon him. He told them what the Prophet, peace be upon him, had said: "Whoever enters the house of Abu Sufyan is safe, and whoever locks his door is safe, and whoever enters the Masjid is safe." So the people dispersed to their homes and to the Masjid.

It is narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, entered Mecca in the year of the Conquest from Kada', which is in the upper part of Mecca. On the day of the Conquest, the Prophet, peace be upon him, declared the blood of some of the polytheists forfeit. He found around the Kaaba three hundred and sixty idols, and he began to strike them with a stick in his hand, saying: "Truth has come, and falsehood has vanished. Truth has come, and falsehood can neither originate nor restore."

The narrations differ regarding the duration of his stay, peace be upon him, in the year of the Conquest. The most probable view, and Allah knows best, is that it was nineteen days.

128.title: The expedition of Khalid ibn al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Uzza in Nakhla.
128.details: When the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, felt secure after the Conquest, he sent Khalid ibn al-Walid to al-Uzza, five nights remaining in this noble month, to demolish it. It was in Nakhla, and it belonged to Quraysh and all of Banu Kinana, and it was their greatest idol. Its custodians were Banu Shayban. Khalid set out to it with thirty horsemen until he reached it and demolished it. When he returned, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, asked him, "Did you see anything?" He said, "No." He said, "Then you did not demolish it. Return to it and demolish it." Khalid returned, enraged, having drawn his sword. A naked, black woman with disheveled hair came out to him. The custodian began to shout at her, and Khalid struck her, cleaving her in two. Then he returned to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, and informed him. He said, "Yes, that was al-Uzza, and she despaired of ever being worshipped in your lands."

129.title: The expedition of Amr ibn al-As, may Allah be pleased with him, to Suwa', the idol of Hudhayl.
129.details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Amr ibn al-As to Suwa' to demolish it. Suwa' was an idol of the people of Noah, peace be upon him. It later belonged to the Banu Hudhayl, a branch of the Mudhar tribe. This idol remained erected, worshipped and venerated by Hudhayl. They even used to make pilgrimage to it until Mecca was conquered and Hudhayl entered the religion of God in multitudes. Its location was in Ruhat, approximately 150 kilometers northeast of Mecca. When Amr arrived, its custodian asked him, "What do you want?" Amr replied, "The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, has commanded me to demolish it." The custodian said, "You cannot do that." Amr asked, "Why?" He replied, "You will be prevented." Amr said, "Are you still on falsehood even now? Woe to you! Does it hear or see?" Then he approached and broke it. He ordered his companions, and they demolished its treasury house, but found nothing in it. Then he said to the custodian, "What did you see?" He replied, "I have submitted to God."

130.title: The expedition of Khalid ibn al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Judhaymah.
130.details: When Khalid ibn al-Walid returned from destroying al-Uzza, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent him to Banu Judhaymah, inviting them to Islam, not to fight them. He set out with three hundred and fifty men from the Muhajirun, the Ansar, and Banu Sulaym. When he reached them, he invited them to Islam, but they did not respond well, saying, "We have embraced Islam," and instead kept saying, "We have apostatized, we have apostatized." Khalid took this as mockery of Islam, as the Quraysh used to say "apostate" to taunt those who embraced Islam. So Khalid began to kill them and take them captive. He handed over a captive to each man who was with him, and one day he ordered each man to kill his captive. Ibn Umar and his companions refused until they came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and told him about it. The Prophet, peace be upon him, raised his hands and said twice: "O Allah, I declare myself innocent of what Khalid has done." Banu Sulaym were the ones who killed their captives, not the Muhajirun and the Ansar. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Ali, who paid the blood money for their slain and compensated for what was lost.

131.title: The Battle of Ta'if after the Muslims besieged it for forty nights.
131.details: After the Muslims pursued the remnants of the fleeing Hawazin in Awṭas and Nakhla, they turned to eliminate Thaqif, who had fled from Hunayn and Awṭas and fortified themselves in their impregnable fortresses in Ta'if. In the Sahih of Muslim, it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and the Muslims with him besieged the polytheists in Ta'if for forty nights. From Abu Najih al-Sulami, he said: "We besieged the fortress of Ta'if with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: 'Whoever hits with an arrow, he shall have a rank in Paradise.' He said: 'On that day, I hit sixteen arrows...'" And twenty-three men fled from that fortress to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. From Abdullah bin Umar, he said: "When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, besieged Ta'if and did not achieve anything from them, he said: 'We are returning, God willing.' This weighed heavily on them, and they said: 'We are leaving without conquering it.' So he said: 'Go forth to battle.' They went forth and sustained injuries. Then he said: 'We are returning tomorrow, God willing.' This pleased them, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, smiled."

132.title: The Battle of Hunayn (Hawazin).
132.details: Hunayn: A valley next to Dhi al-Majaz, near Ta'if. It is a dozen miles from Mecca, in the direction of al-Sharai' and the Great Flood. It is said that it was named Hunayn after a man called Hunayn ibn Qabithah ibn Mahla'il. The Prophet, peace be upon him, had stayed in Mecca for 19 days until Hawazin and Thaqif came and camped in Hunayn, intending to fight the Prophet, peace be upon him. They had gathered before that when they heard of the departure of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from Medina, thinking that he was coming for them. When they learned that he had arrived in Mecca, they began to prepare to confront him. They intended it to be a decisive battle, so they mobilized their wealth, women, and children so that none of them would flee and abandon their families and property. Their leader was Malik ibn 'Awf al-Nadri, and they mobilized Ghatafan and others with them. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prepared to confront them. He borrowed thirty camels and thirty shields from Ya'la ibn Umayyah, and borrowed one hundred shields from Safwan ibn Umayyah. He appointed 'Attab ibn Asid ibn Abi al-'As as governor of Mecca. It is confirmed in the two Sahih collections that the freed slaves (al-tulaqa') went out with him to Hunayn. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, met the enemy with his army in the valley of Hunayn in the early morning. They descended into it, and upon entering the valley, they attacked Hawazin, who were routed. The Muslims then fell upon the spoils they had left behind. While they were in this state, Hawazin confronted them and rained down a volley of arrows upon them. The Muslims had not expected this, and the earth became straitened for them. They turned and fled, not looking back. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, turned to the right, saying: "Where are the people? Come to me! I am the Messenger of Allah! I am the Messenger of Allah! I am Muhammad ibn Abdullah." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered his uncle Al-Abbas – who had a loud voice – to call out to the people to stand firm, specifically mentioning the companions of the Pledge of Ridwan. They rushed to him, then he called out to the Ansar, then to the Banu al-Harith ibn al-Khazraj, and they flew to him, saying: "Labbayk, Labbayk" (Here we are, here we are). A fierce battle ensued against Hawazin. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saw the battle intensifying, he said: "This is when the furnace has heated up." Then he took some pebbles – or dust – and threw them at the faces of the disbelievers, saying: "May the faces be disfigured." No one among them whom Allah created was spared from having his eyes filled with dust from that handful. They turned and fled, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "By the Lord of Muhammad, they are defeated." In another narration: "By the Lord of the Ka'bah, they are defeated! By the Lord of the Ka'bah, they are defeated!" It has been narrated that the killed from Banu Malik of Thaqif alone reached 70. At Awstas, 300 from Banu Malik were killed, and a large number from Banu Nasr ibn Mu'awiyah, then from Banu Ri'ab, were killed. It has been narrated that the captives of Hunayn, women and children, numbered 6,000. Meanwhile, four Muslims were killed.

133.title: The Umrah of Ji'ranah.
133.details: It is established that the Prophet, peace be upon him, performed `Umrah from Al-Ji`ranah in the year of Hunayn. This `Umrah is the third after the `Umrah of Al-Hudaybiyah and the `Umrah of Al-Qada'.
