Ibn Hajar said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, entered the state of Ihram from Al-Ji`ranah and entered Mecca at night, then he completed the rites of `Umrah, and then returned at night and woke up in Al-Ji`ranah as if he had stayed overnight. Ibrahim Al-Nakha`i said: They used to prefer entering Mecca during the day and leaving it at night. And from `Ata': If you wish, enter at night, for you are not like the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He was a leader, and he wanted to enter it during the day so that people could see him. End. The implication of this is that for one who is a leader to be followed, it is recommended for him to enter during the day.

134.title: The death of Umm Kulthum, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.
134.details: She is Umm Kulthum, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him – the fourth noble daughter of the Prophet. Her mother was Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her. It is said that she was married to Utaybah ibn Abi Lahab, then he separated from her. She embraced Islam and migrated after the Prophet, peace be upon him. When her sister Ruqayyah passed away, Uthman married her in Rabi' al-Awwal in the third year (of Hijra), but she did not bear him any children.

135.title: The Year of Delegations.
135.details: Among the most prominent results of the Conquest of Mecca was that the Arab tribes and their individuals began to hasten their embrace of Islam. This was because they had been awaiting the outcome of the conflict between the Muslims and Quraysh. Amr ibn Salamah narrated, saying: "We used to be at a watering place where people passed by, and travelers would pass us. We would ask them, 'What is happening with the people? What is happening with the people? Who is this man?' They would say, 'He claims that Allah sent him, and revealed to him – or: Allah revealed such and such.' I would memorize those words, as if they were imprinted in my chest. The Arabs used to delay their Islam until the Conquest, saying, 'Leave him and his people. If he prevails over them, then he is a true prophet.' So, when the Conquest of Mecca occurred, every tribe hastened to embrace Islam, and my father hastened my people to embrace Islam."

136.title: The obligation of Hajj was revealed.
136.details: Pilgrimage was known before the prophethood. Abraham called people to pilgrimage, and Moses and other prophets performed it. Pilgrimage remained known, but the polytheists altered it as they pleased. The first to make alterations was Amr ibn Luhayy. Then, Allah the Almighty ordained pilgrimage upon Muslims who are able to undertake the journey, saying: {And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House, for whoever is able to find thereto a way} [Al-Imran: 97]. The Messenger, peace be upon him, explained its rites in full during the Farewell Pilgrimage in the year 10 AH. There is disagreement regarding the year pilgrimage was ordained; it is said to have been ordained in the year six, or in the year seven, or in the year eight, or other opinions exist.

137.title: The death of the Negus, the ruler of Abyssinia, may Allah be pleased with him.
137.details: He is Ashama ibn Abjar, the King of Abyssinia. "Najashi" is a title for him and the kings of Abyssinia. The meaning of "Ashama" is "gift," and it is also said to mean "gift of God" or "generosity." He assumed rule after the death of his uncle. Years after his reign and the spread of his justice, he embraced Islam during the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him. He treated the Muslims who migrated to his land with kindness. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to his companions about the Najashi: "If you were to go to the land of Abyssinia, there is a king there under whom no one is wronged. It is a land of truth, until Allah grants you a way out." When he died, the Prophet, peace be upon him, led the funeral prayer in absentia for him in Medina. Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, reported that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, informed them of the death of the Najashi, the ruler of Abyssinia, on the day he died, and said: "Ask forgiveness for your brother." Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, reported that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said when the Najashi died: "A righteous man died today. So, stand up and offer the funeral prayer for your brother Ashama."

138.title: The Battle of Tabuk and the Army of Hardship.
138.details:
Tabuk is a place between Wadi al-Qura and Sham. Abu Musa al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "My companions sent me to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to ask him for mounts for them, as they were with him in the Army of Hardship, which was the expedition to Tabuk..."

The hadith of Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, indicates the severe hardship the Companions faced in terms of wealth, provisions, and mounts. As narrated by Muslim, also from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, the Muslims suffered from a lack of provisions on the way to this expedition, to the extent that they sucked the date pits and drank water with them. In another narration by Muslim, they asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for permission to slaughter their mounts to eat. And Allah Almighty said: {Allah has turned in forgiveness to the Prophet and to the Emigrants and Helpers who followed him in the hour of hardship, after the hearts of a party of them had falved. Then He turned to them in forgiveness. Indeed, He is to them Kind and Merciful.} [Quran 9:117].

Ibn Kathir said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, resolved to fight the Romans because they were the closest people to him and the most deserving of being invited to the truth due to their proximity to Islam and its people. And Allah Almighty said: {O you who have believed, fight those adjacent to you of the disbelievers and let them find harshness in you, and know that Allah is with the righteous.} [Quran 9:123].

The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, clarified the objective of this expedition. From Mu'adh, may Allah be pleased with him, it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "You will arrive tomorrow, Allah willing, at the spring of Tabuk. You will not reach it until the day has brightened. So whoever among you arrives there, let him not touch any of its water until I come."

The well-known and preferred opinion is that the army of Tabuk numbered thirty thousand. However, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not encounter any fighting from the enemy. He returned to Medina victorious after staying in Tabuk for twenty nights.

139.title: The death of the head of the hypocrites, Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul.
139.details: He is Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul, the head of the hypocrites. He fell ill in the remaining nights of Shawwal after the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned from the Battle of Tabuk. When he died, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sought forgiveness for him and prayed over him after Umar attempted to prevent him from praying over him. The Quran was revealed thereafter, agreeing with Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, only prayed over him to uphold the outward ruling, which was Islam, and for the religious benefit of reconciling the hearts of his people and followers. A large group of hypocrites pledged allegiance to him, so perhaps they would be influenced, turn away from their hypocrisy, take heed, and become sincere to Allah and His Messenger.

140.title: The Pilgrimage of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq and the Revelation of Surat Bara'ah.
140.details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent Abu Bakr as the commander of the Hajj after the end of Dhu al-Qi'dah to perform the Hajj for the Muslims. The polytheists were still performing their Hajj in their usual way. Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, and the Muslims with him set out. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, also sent Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, after Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, to be with him. Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, was to personally deliver the declaration of disassociation to the polytheists on behalf of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, as he was his cousin and from his kin. Abu Hurayrah said: Abu Bakr sent me on that Hajj with some callers to prayer on the Day of Sacrifice, announcing in Mina: "No polytheist shall perform Hajj after this year, and no one shall circumambulate the House naked." Humayd ibn 'Abd al-Rahman said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Ali after him and ordered him to announce the declaration of disassociation. Abu Hurayrah said: Ali announced with us among the people of Mina on the Day of Sacrifice: "No polytheist shall perform Hajj after this year, and no one shall circumambulate the House naked."

141.title: The succession of delegations to the Prophet, peace be upon him.
141.details: The delegations continued to arrive to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him. Among them was the delegation of the Christians of Najran, and he made peace with them, stipulating the jizya (poll tax) and granting them protection.

142.title: The death of Ibrahim, son of the Prophet, peace be upon him.
142.details: Ibrahim was the son of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his mother was Maria al-Qibtiyya. All of the Prophet's children, peace be upon him, were from Khadijah, may Allah be pleased with her, except for Ibrahim, who was from Maria al-Qibtiyya the Egyptian, may Allah be pleased with her. Anas ibn Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I have not seen anyone more compassionate to children than the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He said: Ibrahim was being nursed in the high lands of Medina. The Prophet, peace be upon him, would go with us, and we would enter the house, and it would be smoky. His wet nurse was a blacksmith. He would take him, kiss him, and then return." Amr said: When Ibrahim died, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, Ibrahim is my son, and he died while still nursing. He has two wet nurses who will complete his nursing in Paradise." Al-Mughira ibn Shu'bah said: The sun was eclipsed during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on the day Ibrahim died. The people said: The sun was eclipsed because of Ibrahim's death. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The sun and the moon do not eclipse for the death of anyone, nor for their life. When you see that, then pray and supplicate to Allah." Abu Bakra said: The sun was eclipsed during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He went out, dragging his cloak, until he reached the mosque. The people gathered around him. He led them in two rak'ahs, and the sun became clear. He said: "The sun and the moon are two signs from the signs of Allah, and they do not eclipse for the death of anyone. When that happens, then pray and supplicate until what is with you is revealed." This was because a son of the Prophet, peace be upon him, died, and he was called Ibrahim. The people spoke about this. Ibrahim was born to him in Medina from his concubine Maria al-Qibtiyya in the year eight of the Hijra. His freedman Abu Rafi' gave him the good news, so he gave him a slave. He died as an infant before weaning, and there is a difference of opinion as to whether he prayed over him or not, with two opinions.

143.title: The Farewell Pilgrimage, also known as the Pilgrimage of Islam or the Pilgrimage of Conveyance.
143.details: It was named the Farewell Pilgrimage because the Prophet, peace be upon him, bid farewell to the people during it, and he did not perform Hajj after it. It was also named the Pilgrimage of Islam because the Prophet, peace be upon him, did not perform Hajj from Medina except for this one. It was also named the Pilgrimage of Conveyance because the Prophet, peace be upon him, conveyed to the people the law of Allah in Hajj, both in word and deed. There was nothing left of the pillars and foundations of Islam that the Prophet, peace be upon him, had not clarified. When he clarified, elucidated, and explained the Sharia of Hajj to them, Allah, the Exalted, revealed to him while he was standing at Arafat: "{This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islam as religion}" [Al-Ma'idah: 3]. When the Messenger, peace be upon him, announced his intention to perform Hajj in that year, a large number of people came to Medina, all seeking to follow the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and perform Hajj like him. He set out from Medina five nights before the end of Dhu al-Qi'dah. Many events occurred for the Prophet, peace be upon him, during this journey and his return.

145.title: The greatest calamity for the Muslims was the death of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him.
145.details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, fell ill after his return from the Farewell Pilgrimage, until his pain intensified while he was in the house of Maymunah, may God be pleased with her. He called his wives and asked their permission to be nursed in the house of Aisha, may God be pleased with her. Aisha, may God be pleased with her, said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say during his illness in which he died: "O Aisha, I still feel the pain of the food I ate in Khaybar, and now is the time when I feel my aorta breaking from that poison." His illness lasted for ten days. Ibn Hajar said: (There is a difference of opinion regarding the duration of his illness. The majority hold that it was thirteen days, and it was said that it was one day more, and it was said that it was one day less, and it was said: ten days. Sulayman al-Taymi was certain of this in his accounts of battles, and al-Bayhaqi narrated it with a sound chain of transmission). Then God Almighty took him on Monday, the twelfth of Rabi' al-Awwal, and he was 63 years old. He was shrouded, peace and blessings be upon him, in three white Sahuliyyah garments made of cotton, which did not include a shirt or a turban. The people prayed over him in groups, and he was buried in the place of his death in the chamber of Aisha, may God be pleased with her. May God Almighty reward him on behalf of the Muslims with the best reward He has ever given a prophet for his people.

6103.title: The revolt of Al-Aswad Al-Ansi in Yemen and his killing at the hands of Firuz al-Daylami.
6103.details: Al-Aswad al-Ansi – whose name was Abhalah ibn Ka'b ibn Gawth – emerged in the final days of the life of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with seven hundred fighters. He wrote to the agents of the Prophet, peace be upon him, saying: "O rebels against us, return to us what you have taken from our land, and keep what you have gathered, for we are more deserving of it, and you remain as you are." Then he proceeded with his fighters to Najran and captured it. Afterward, he intended for Sana'a. Shahar ibn Bazham came out to him, and they fought. Al-Aswad defeated and killed him, and married Shahar ibn Bazham's wife, who was the daughter of Fayruz al-Daylami's cousin. Her name was Azadh, and she was a believer in Allah and His Messenger, peace be upon him, and among the righteous. Al-Ansi occupied Sana'a. Mu'adh ibn Jabal and Abu Musa al-Ash'ari went to Hadhramaut, and the agents of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, retreated to Al-Tahir. Umar ibn Haram and Khalid ibn Sa'id ibn al-'As returned to Medina. Yemen became secured for Al-Aswad al-Ansi, and his affair began to spread like wildfire. His rule intensified, and his situation grew grave. A group of the people of Yemen apostatized. The Muslims there dealt with him with dissimulation. When the news of Al-Aswad al-Ansi reached him, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent his letter with Qays ibn Makshuh, ordering the Muslims there to fight and confront Al-Ansi. Mu'adh ibn Jabal took charge of this letter perfectly. Mu'adh ibn Jabal and those who rallied around him from the people of Yemen, and Qays ibn Abd Yaghuth, the commander of Al-Aswad's army, and Fayruz al-Daylami, agreed to assassinate Al-Aswad and kill him. They pledged to do so. When night fell, they entered his house. Fayruz al-Daylami approached him. Al-Aswad was sleeping on a silk mattress, his head sunk into his body, snoring heavily, with the woman sitting beside him. Fayruz attacked him and grappled with him, who was like a camel. He seized his head, crushed his neck, and placed his knees on his back until he killed him. Qays, Dadhuwayh, and Fayruz sat planning how to inform their followers. They agreed that in the morning, they would call out their rallying cry, which was between them and the Muslims. When morning came, one of them – Qays – stood on the rampart of the fortress and called out their rallying cry. The Muslims and the disbelievers gathered around the fortress. Qays then cried out: "I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, and that Abhalah is a liar!" He threw his head down to them. His followers fled, and people pursued them, capturing and ambushing them on every road, taking them prisoner. Islam and its adherents prevailed. The deputies of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned to their posts. They agreed that Mu'adh ibn Jabal would lead the people in prayer. They wrote the news to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The duration of his rule, from his emergence until his death, was three or four months.
